On May 14, a TikTok account RoLeak shared a disturbing animated video titled "Courtney Winston's car accident." The account claimed in the caption that it was an animated demonstration of a real incident that took place in 2016.  It further stated that the video of the incident was taken in Florida, where a 34-year-old person named Courtney Winston ran over a group of college students in an unfortunate accident, and none of the victims survived the impact of the hit.  Now TikTok users were confused as they tried to decipher whether or not the claim was true. Such notorious claims are not unusual on social media, as many accounts on different social media platforms are dedicated to spreading hoaxes and false and deceptive claims to baffle viewers.  However, no car accident involving that name and a group of college students was reported in December 2016. There is no other evidence supporting the supposed incident either.  TikTok users react to Courtney Winston car accident claim  The animated clip shared by @rbxleak is only a couple of seconds long, where a car is shown driving down a road. It‚Äôs displayed from a first-person perspective, like racing games. Then suddenly, the car collides with a group of people trying to cross the road, and the victims are seen immediately flown across the road. A loud screeching of a female is heard.  Here's how some people on TikTok reacted to the video:  TikTok users react to animated Courtney Winston car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  While most people in the comments already realized that the video was fake and was probably taken from some game, some were confused because of the realistic audio and wondered if the audio was from a real incident.  In most of the comments, users played along with the joke and commented ‚Äúsending prayers from‚Äù and then added some hilarious names of different places.  TikTok users react to animated Courtney Winston car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  TikTok users react to the animated car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  TikTok users react to the animated car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  TikTok users react to the animated car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  TikTok users react to the animated car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  TikTok users react to the animated car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  TikTok users react to the animated car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  In response to many users who flooded the comment section with questions regarding the authenticity of the video, the creator clarified that it was not a serious video and said that they were not aware of the source of the audio.  TikTok users react to animated Courtney Winston car accident video. (Image via TikTok/@rbxleak)  The audio was evidently attached to the animation from a game to convince users that it was real. However, this whole car accident by someone named Courtney Winson is fabricated.  The TikTok account that uploaded the video solely makes Roblox videos with claims that have no base in reality. These videos are meant for dark entertainment and aim to lure viewers with these intriguing but false claims.  Poll : 0 votes

STANTON, Neb. (KCAU) ‚Äî A woman was taken to a hospital with serious injuries after what officials are calling a ‚Äúfreak accident‚Äù on Tuesday.  At 4:55 p.m. officials were called to investigate a crash on Highway 24, according to a release from the Stanton County Sheriff‚Äôs office.  The release states that the investigation found that a 77-year-old woman was traveling west on Highway 24 when the driver‚Äôs side door to her van partially opened. Officials believe the driver was trying to close the door when she lost control of the vehicle.  The van then crossed over the eastbound lane before entering the south ditch while at highway speeds. The release states the woman fell through the open door while the vehicle continued moving through a grove of trees and fence line. The car finally came to a stop in a farm field.  Officials arrived on the scene to find the woman unconscious. She was taken to a nearby hospital for treatment of her injuries. She was allegedly not wearing her seatbelt at the time of the crash, according to the release.

CHEROKEE, Iowa (KTIV) - A northwest Iowa man has been arrested for his alleged involvement in a hit-and-run accident that resulted in the death of a bicyclist.  Online court documents show 29-year-old Casey Herwig of Cherokee, Iowa is facing one charge of knowingly leaving the scene of an accident resulting in death. The charge comes from an incident that happened in Cherokee back on Dec. 26, 2022.  Authorities say at about 8:30 p.m. they received a call about a bicyclist laying in the roadway at the intersection of N 6th Street and West Willow.  An investigation determined Herwig was the one who hit the bicyclist while driving a pickup. When authorities found Herwig‚Äôs pickup, they allegedly found damage on the front of the vehicle that matched parts found at the scene of the accident.  According to court documents, Herwig told officers that he knew he hit something, but he wasn‚Äôt sure what it was. When asked by officers if it was possible he hit a person, Herwig reportedly said that it ‚Äúcould‚Äôve been.‚Äù  Documents identify the bicyclist as Phillip Watterson, a resident of Cherokee. CRITTENDEN, Ky. (WXIX) - The family of a Northern Kentucky man is in despair after their loved one was removed from life support three months after a tragic farm accident.  Larry Posey, 74, passed on Mother‚Äôs Day from injuries he suffered after he was run over by a tractor while working on a farm along Duncan Road in Crittenden.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dead inside,‚Äù said Tracey Deleon, Posey‚Äôs daughter. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dying right now. It‚Äôs like, killing me.‚Äù  Deleon is in gut-wrenching pain without her father.  ‚ÄúEvery night I‚Äôm on my back porch, sitting away from the kids so they don‚Äôt see the emotions, until 3 a.m. I‚Äôm crying out on the porch by myself,‚Äù Deleon said.  The accident happened on Feb. 13 as Posey was helping a friend repair a tractor on the farm he owns. Deleon says later that evening, they got the call.  ‚ÄúThere were a couple of different stories. First, it was told that once the filter was put on, the tractor jumped out of gear and ran over him,‚Äù she said ‚ÄúThen another story was told that he was under it... We‚Äôre not sure exactly which of those stories is the truth.‚Äù  UC Air Care flew her father to the University of Cincinnati Medical Center with a fractured skull, fractured ribs and a punctured lung. He was placed on life support and eventually transferred to The Christ Hospital, where he would die three months later.  ‚ÄúWith him gone, that leaves us with nothing,‚Äù Deleon said. ‚ÄúI call his cell phone just to hear his voice on his voicemail. I‚Äôm lost.‚Äù  She says the work her father was doing that day was typical of the man renowned locally as a handyman who didn‚Äôt mind getting his hands dirty and bending over backward for those who needed him.  ‚ÄúHe would come up and help on the farm to not be sitting,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe would cut the grass, he would take care of the cows, and he would take care of the horses... He was a great person. The best.‚Äù  Deleon says Posey was a retired coal miner and a major financial provider for the family. Now she‚Äôs hopeful an online fundraiser created in his honor will raise enough to cover his funeral expenses.  ‚ÄúMy dad was amazing. He was amazing. He taught me everything I need to know about car work. He was always there for me. Always there for me,‚Äù she said ‚ÄúHe deserves to be buried with dignity and respect. No matter what I have to do.‚Äù  The family is working with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to determine what exactly happened.  See a spelling or grammar error in our story? Two McMinn County High School students were killed on Tuesday in an automobile accident. Two other students were injured in the accident.  The students who were killed were Cameron Bohannon, 17, and Robert Hicks, 18. Both were set to graduate soon.  The accident happened on County Road 750 where it intersects with County Road 655.

Our Correspondent  Fatehgarh Sahib, May 17  A scooterist was today killed in a road accident on the Mandi Gobindgarh-Nabha road. The said road is known often called ‚Äòkiller road‚Äô due to its poor condition, particularly within the limits of the Municipal Councils of Mandi Gobindgarh and Amloh.  The road has been playing havoc with the lives of the public and accidents here have become a routine.  The deceased has been identified as Jaswinder Singh of Shanti Nagar. He was working as a peon at the Motia Khan branch of Union Bank. As per the police, the deceased was returning home after duty. As he reached near a restaurant on the Amloh road, a speeding truck hit his scooter. Jaswinder fell on the ground and was crushed by the truck. He died on the spot.  The Mandi Gobindgarh-Nabha road, which connects the area with Sangrur and Malwa, has been in a poor condition since long. Potholes and plying of trucks loaded with heavy iron material on the road not only cause great inconvenience to the commuters but also poses a threat to their lives. Trucks loaded with iron often overturn due to the potholes.  Harpreet Singh Prince, president of the Mandi Gobindgarh Municipal Council said earlier there was a toll plaza on the road, but the contractor shut it and left the road at the mercy of the authorities. Since then, neither the municipal councils nor the government initiated the repair work of the road, he said.  During the Assembly elections, the sitting AAP MLA had promised that it would be his priority to get the road repaired if his party came to power. But nothing has been done so far even though the party has completed more than one year in power.  The condition of the road worsened after it was dug up for laying sewerage lines. Trucks carrying iron material are parked on the roadside, leading to snarl-ups and causing accidents.  The residents have been demanding the repairing of the road for long, but no one has paid any heed to their demands.  Road in poor shape  Potholes and plying of trucks laden with heavy iron material on the road pose a great threat to the lives of commuters. Trucks often overturn due to the potholes. These can also be seen parked on the roadside, leading to snarl-ups and causing accidents. The condition of the road worsened after it was dug up for the laying of sewerage lines.  #fatehgarh sahib

Edna, Iowa ‚Äî A Rock Rapids man has died as the result of an accident near Edna on Wednesday, May 17, 2023.  The Iowa State Patrol reports that at about 11:10 a.m., 82-year-old Dennis Hayenga of Little Rock was driving a 2007 International tank truck owned by Farmers Coop Society westbound on 180th Street, about a mile northeast of Edna. They tell us that 77-year-old Myron Krull of Rock Rapids was westbound on 180th on a 1963 Farmall farm tractor.  The report says that Hayenga attempted to pass the tractor and struck the left rear corner of the sprayer that Krull was towing. The report says the sprayer came detached from the tractor and rolled. The tractor also rolled into the north ditch.  Krull died as a result of his injuries. Hayenga reported no injuries.  The trooper says the Lyon County Sheriff‚Äôs Office, Lyon County Ambulance Squad, George Fire Department, and George Emergency Medical Service assisted with the response to the accident.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. (WIAT) ‚Äî On Wednesday, UAB honored trauma survivors, their families and the doctors that treated them.  Wil Raines is a survivor who said he‚Äôs alive today and able to live out his dream of being a father because of the care from trauma specialists at UAB.  Raines is a familiar face here at CBS 42. As a photojournalist, he is an integral part of our team, capturing the heart of stories through the camera lens but it‚Äôs his heart that‚Äôs taking center stage.  Raines is a car accident survivor and thanks to doctors at UAB‚Äôs Trauma Center, he is able to share his story of survival.  ‚ÄúGoing across four lanes of traffic changed the rest of my life,‚Äù Raines said.  It was the day after Christmas, 1997 when young Raines‚Äô life flashed before his eyes.  ‚ÄúPeople at the Chevron said ‚ÄòMan, there was a bag that went flying out that car.‚Äô [In reality] that was me,‚Äù Raines said.  He had hopped in his friend‚Äôs Bronco. They were meeting friends at the gas station down the street when they got in a car accident.  ‚ÄúI always wear my seatbelt. But you know, you jump in the car and run across the street, run a mile down the street go see a friend. You don‚Äôt think about it. I didn‚Äôt think about it,‚Äù Raines said.  A car crashed into them causing the Bronco to flip three times throwing Raines out of the car.  ‚ÄúEverything turned white, and it was completely quiet. Growing up as a person of faith I knew exactly what it was. I wasn‚Äôt scared,‚Äù Raines said.  The crash happened in Prattville, miles from UAB‚Äôs Trauma Center. He had a broken arm, collapsed lung and a stage-five laceration on his liver, causing him to bleed out.  ‚ÄúI saw my mom and my dad and the last thing I said to them for a few weeks was pray for me,‚Äù Raines said.  His family doctor, Dr. Charles Cloutier knew Raines‚Äô chances of survival were running out. It was a cold, rainy December night and Cloutier said the medivac was grounded because of the weather. He pulled some strings and got an ambulance from Prattville to take Raines to Birmingham. He rode with him the entire way giving him blood and fluids along the way.  ‚ÄúWe got him to UAB about 4 a.m. and UAB took over. They were professional, excellent. We felt very comfortable with Wil being here at UAB. It‚Äôs a time that‚Äôs embedded in your brain and will not go away. It was a traumatic event for everyone involved. Wil was a trooper,‚Äù Dr. Cloutier said.  Thankfully the surgeries were a success. It was the beginning of a long road to recovery. He had been given a second chance at life.  ‚ÄúIf it weren‚Äôt for them, I wouldn‚Äôt have my son. If it weren‚Äôt for them, I wouldn‚Äôt be standing here talking to y‚Äôall,‚Äù Raines said.  And this Wednesday, Raines got to thank that doctor in person at UAB‚Äôs Trauma Survivors‚Äô Day.  ‚ÄúI just want to give him a hug. I was talking to my mom, and I said what can I get him. He‚Äôs the one that saved my life,‚Äù Raines said.  Raines said it‚Äôs because of doctors like Dr. Cloutier and centers like UAB‚Äôs Trauma Center that so many people get to live a long and healthy life.

PARK CITY, Utah ‚Äî The friend of a man injured in a climbing accident last week has created a GoFundMe in the hope of raise enough money to cover his medical expenses.  On Friday, May 12, 30-year-old Scotty Hogg and his girlfriend 34-year-old Kaitlyn Brann were climbing Goodro‚Äôs Wall in Big Cottonwood Canyon when a large rock on the route gave way, causing both the climbers to fall. Brann was killed in the accident, and Hogg was transported to the hospital by helicopter with serious injuries.  The fundraiser was organized by Cory Lamkins, a friend of Hogg‚Äôs. Lamkins and Hogg met in 2017 while they were stationed in Iraq serving in the Army. Lamkins described Hogg as an avid outdoor enthusiast and a very dependable friend.  ‚ÄúHe loves being outdoors and in nature,‚Äù Lamkins said. ‚ÄúIf you call and you need something, he will help whether it‚Äôs in person or whether he spends all his days calling anybody he knows that can help you out closer to you. He‚Äôs always a guy that if you need him, he‚Äôs there.‚Äù  Although Lamkins had not met Brann in person, he said that he had spoken to her on the phone several times during calls with Hogg.  ‚ÄúI did not get to meet her in person, sadly, but I will say anybody that had the energy to love Scott must have been a pretty incredible person, because he‚Äôs all go all the time,‚Äù Lamkins said.  Hogg is still in the hospital where he is working with physical therapists to regain mobility after the accident.  ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs got a long road ahead of him to fully recover,‚Äù Lamkins said. ‚ÄúJust like anybody who lost someone days ago, you know, he‚Äôs mentally going through your grinder, but all the love and support it‚Äôs really been helping him stay out of dark times.‚Äù  At the time of this article $9,030 had been donated out of the GoFundMe‚Äôs $20,000 goal. According to Lamkins, all donated funds that surpass the $20,000 goal will be donated to Brann‚Äôs family to help cover funeral expenses.

One person has been killed as the result of a traffic accident in Wilkes County last Friday (May 12). The deceased is 31-year-old Obed Ulises Garcia of Moravian Falls.  At about 12:50 a.m. Friday, the North Carolina State Highway Patrol responded to the accident near Cain Ridge Road. A southbound 2004 Nissan Maxima traveling on Moravian Falls Road ran off the right side of the road, then back onto the roadway where it crossed the center line, traveled off the left side of the road, ran into a ditch, overturned, and came to rest on the passenger side.  Mr. Garcia, who was driving, was critically injured and was transported by E.M.S. to Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist Medical Center in Winston Salem. He passed away on May 15. Mr. Garcia was wearing a seatbelt, but was ejected from the vehicle.  The initial investigation indicates excessive speed to be the contributing circumstance in the collision. During the on-scene investigation, Moravian Falls Road was closed in the area for an hour.

The Wilmington Police Department has identified a bicyclist struck and killed in an accident by the intersection of Oleander Drive and Independence Boulevard on Tuesday night.  He was identified as 79-year-old Edward Lillis. He died at the scene.  Officers came to the site near Independence Mall just before 7 p.m. after the traffic collision. A corporal from Wilmington police was first on the scene. He was travelling in the lane next to the vehicle that struck Lillis. The officer and the driver provided aid to the biker and tried to save his life.  An investigation began. Westbound lanes of Oleander Drive were closed to traffic for an extended period of time after officers responded to the scene. It was discovered that Lillis was crossing westbound traffic on Oleander Drive without having the right of way. As Lillis entered the roadway, he was struck by the vehicle.  Brandon Shope, a spokesman for the department, reported that no criminal charges have been filed. CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa (KCRG) - On May 14th, 2023 at approximately 3:00 am, Cedar Rapids Police responded to the 2100 block of Williams Boulevard Southwest for a traffic accident.  Investigators say a car headed east on Williams Boulevard spun out of control and hit an SUV going in the opposite direction.  Two individuals died as a result of the accident. Police have named 23-year-old Aja Dampier and 29-year-old John De Lapaz from Cedar Rapids as the two victims.  Three others were taken to a nearby hospital for treatment of their injuries.  Police are asking witnesses or people with video footage of the crash to come forward as it is still under investigation.  Copyright 2023 KCRG. All rights reserved.

Death Benefits Wrongfully Denied to Woman Whose Fianc√© Died in Industrial Accident  A woman whose fianc√© and father of her children died in an industrial accident was wrongfully denied death benefits solely because she was not his spouse, the Supreme Court of Ohio ruled today.  In a unanimous per curiam opinion, the Supreme Court ruled the Ohio Industrial Commission did not completely analyze the death benefits law, but instead focused only on whether Amanda Carpenter was Christopher McDonald‚Äôs wife. An unmarried person in a relationship with the deceased is not ‚Äúpresumed‚Äù to be entitled to death benefits under the law, but a case-by-case inquiry needs to be made under such circumstances.  The Court vacated the industrial commission‚Äôs order and directed it to determine if Carpenter is entitled to death benefits as a ‚Äúmember of McDonald‚Äôs family.‚Äù  Click to Expand  Benefit Denial Contested  In 2019, McDonald died in a ditch collapse. Carpenter, the mother of McDonald‚Äôs two minor children, applied to the Bureau of Workers‚Äô Compensation for death benefits on behalf of the children and herself.  Carpenter identified herself as McDonald‚Äôs fianc√©e. She provided a sworn statement that she and McDonald had been in a relationship for 11 years and jointly owned property. The two were jointly responsible for mortgage and vehicle lease payments and credit card debts. Each had life insurance policies naming the other as the sole beneficiary. Carpenter indicated she worked part-time, and McDonald was the primary financial support for her and their two children. She added that they ‚Äúhad every intention of being married if not for this accident.‚Äù  A district hearing officer awarded benefits to the children, but not to Carpenter. She appealed and a staff hearing officer awarded her death benefits as well. The order was then appealed to the industrial commission, which vacated the decision of its staff hearing officer and denied Carpenter death benefits.  The commission determined Carpenter was not dependent on McDonald as a surviving spouse because they were never married and they could not be considered married under common law because Ohio abolished common-law marriage in 1991. The commission also stated that case law has not extended the benefit to ‚Äúan unmarried person in a relationship‚Äù with the deceased, as Carpenter suggested.  Carpenter requested a writ of mandamus from the Tenth District Court of Appeals ordering the industrial commission to reverse its decision and award her death benefits. The Tenth District did so, and the industrial commission appealed the decision to the Supreme Court.  Supreme Court Analyzed Death Benefit Law  Payment of death benefits to the dependents of a worker who died on the job is governed by R.C. 4123.59(D), the opinion explained. The law explains that a surviving spouse living with the employee at the time of death is presumed to be wholly dependent on the deceased and entitled to death benefits.  The law says a ‚Äúmember of the family‚Äù may be a ‚Äúprospective dependent‚Äù if the person also ‚Äúbears to the deceased employee the relation of surviving spouse, lineal descendant, ancestor, or brother or sister.‚Äù The industrial commission may take any facts into consideration that indicate the person‚Äôs prospective dependency.  In all other cases, the commission must decide ‚Äúin accordance with the facts in each particular case‚Äù if the person is ‚Äúa member of the family of the deceased employee, or bears to the deceased employee the relation of surviving spouse, lineal descendant, ancestor, or brother or sister.‚Äù  The Court stated this last paragraph of the law applies to claims brought by a person not presumed to be a dependent of the employee, and may even apply to a surviving spouse if the spouse was not living with the employee at the time of death.  The opinion stated that the last paragraph of R.C. 4123.59(D) provides two potential categories of dependents. One is a member of the family of the deceased employee. The second is a person who ‚Äúbears to the deceased employee the relation of surviving spouse, lineal descendant, ancestor, or brother or sister.‚Äù Because the sentence contains an ‚Äúor,‚Äù a person does not have to be married to the deceased employee to be a member of the family, the Court ruled.  The law indicates ‚Äúany‚Äù person may be eligible for benefits if that person is determined to be ‚Äúa member of the family,‚Äù the opinion stated. Ohio workers‚Äô compensation laws do not define ‚Äúmember of the family.‚Äù When denying Carpenter benefits, the commission did not consider or determine whether she was a member of McDonald‚Äôs family, the opinion stated.  The commission argued that for more than 80 years, the law in Ohio required a legal marriage before it was required to pay death benefits. The opinion noted the commission used cases from 1922 and 1957 to support its argument.  The Court pointed to more recent cases in which stepchildren who were not formally adopted, but lived with and were dependent on the deceased employee, were considered members of the family and were awarded death benefits.  The opinion stated the commission could consider that an unmarried person in a relationship with the deceased is a member of the family. The Court pointed to definitions in Black‚Äôs Law Dictionary that could include Carpenter. For instance, one definition of ‚Äúfamily‚Äù in the law dictionary is ‚Äúa group consisting of parents and their children,‚Äù the opinion noted. Another is ‚Äúa group of people who live together and usu[ally] have a shared commitment to a domestic relationship.‚Äù  ‚ÄúAccordingly ‚Äî as these definitions show ‚Äî it is very well possible that Carpenter could qualify as a ‚Äòmember of the family of the deceased employee,‚Äô‚Äù the Court concluded. ‚ÄúWhether Carpenter actually qualifies as a ‚Äòmember of the family of the deceased employee‚Äô under the particular facts of this case is a question that the commission will have to address.‚Äù  2022-0143. State ex rel. McDonald v. Indus. Comm., Slip Opinion No. 2023-Ohio-1620.  Please note: Opinion summaries are prepared by the Office of Public Information for the general public and news media. Opinion summaries are not prepared for every opinion, but only for noteworthy cases. Opinion summaries are not to be considered as official headnotes or syllabi of court opinions. The full text of this and other court opinions are available online.

AMERICUS, Ind. ‚Äî Rene Goforth, of Darlington, Ind., was driving the 2001 Ford Expedition that crashed Wednesday afternoon, according to the Tippecanoe County Sheriff's Office.  The crash left a 7-year-old boy dead and sent Goforth and five other passengers to various area hospitals.  Among the injured, including Goforth being treated at an Indianapolis hospital, were Nikita Penn, 24, of Lafayette, also at an Indianapolis hospital, and Brandon Hudson, 23, of Plymouth, Ind., taken to a hospital in Lafayette, according to the sheriff's office. Their injuries were described Wednesday afternoon as life-threatening.  Wednesday evening, Tippecanoe County Coroner Carrie Costello released the age of the deceased but was waiting to inform the next of kin before releasing the name of the boy. An autopsy was scheduled for Thursday.  The 7-year-old who died was a backseat passenger, along with two other injured juveniles who were ultimately transported to Indianapolis hospitals for further treatment, the sheriff's office stated.  The crash remains under investigation with the crash reconstruction team.  Tippecanoe County law enforcement were notified of a personal injury crash in the 6400 block of Old State Road around 1:30 p.m. Wednesday, according to Tippecanoe County Sheriff‚Äôs Office.  When first responders arrived at the scene of the accident, they discovered a single vehicle had rolled over and ended up resting on its side, according to the sheriff‚Äôs office.  There were three juveniles and three adults in the vehicle at the time of the accident, according to the sheriff‚Äôs office.  The vehicle was traveling southbound on Old State Road 25 when it went off the road leading to the crash. Several occupants were ejected from the vehicle according to police. The Tippecanoe County Sheriff‚Äôs Office Crash Reconstruction Team is currently investigating the crash to determine the cause of the accident.  Americus is within Tippecanoe County.  At the time of reporting, the sheriff‚Äôs office had not released the name and ages of the occupants of the accident, as they were still investigating the crash.  Crews from the Buck Creek Fire Department, Battle Ground Fire Department, Lafayette Fire Department and Tippecanoe Emergency Ambulance Service arrived on scene with deputies. The Indiana State Police and Tippecanoe County Coroner‚Äôs Office assisted with the investigation, according to the sheriff‚Äôs office.  The Journal & Courier will update this article as more information becomes available.  Noe Padilla is a reporter for the Journal & Courier. SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (Dakota News Now) - As springtime weather sticks around, you‚Äôve probably noticed more cyclists on the roads. One ride in Sioux Falls promoted a special message, commemorating those killed and supporting those injured while riding on public roads.  Falls Area Bicyclists invited all bicyclists to participate in a ‚ÄòRide of Silence‚Äô Wednesday.  ‚ÄúRide of Silence‚Äù is a slow-paced bike ride in coordination with the World Wide National ‚ÄòRide of Silence‚Äô to honor accident victims and promote safe cycling.  For many, this ride is personal.  Julia, who was riding for her relative Colin said, ‚ÄúOn the 28th it will be nine months ago that Colin was hit while he was riding his bike to work.‚Äù  The ride is also a reminder about the importance of safety on the roads.  ‚ÄúCollin was really safe when he would bike, he had flashing lights and would always do all of the precautions to make it where he was more visible,‚Äù Julia explained.  Julia believes events like the ‚ÄòRide of Silence‚Äô can help to prevent more accidents from happening as well as bring healing to those impacted.  ‚ÄúI think awareness is a big piece for us, it‚Äôs a part of why the ghost bike is so important and having that where we‚Äôre seeing each other in community,‚Äù Julia said.  Pastor Jason Mueller, with New Haven Ministries bikes daily around Sioux Falls  He shared why he believes the ‚ÄòRide of Silence‚Äô can be so impactful.  ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs healthy anytime we can reflect on when we‚Äôve has some kind emotional pain for struggle so for me it‚Äôs always important to take time and reflect,‚Äù Mueller explained.  Time to reflect on an important message for cyclists and drivers.  ‚ÄúWe all know that we need to share the roads, motorcycles, different alternate transportation, as well as bicycles, and this ride of silence is to commemorate and remember anybody‚Äôs who‚Äôs ever been hit by a car, or another vehicle, as well as those who have lost their lives,‚Äù Mueller said.  Collin‚Äôs family and organizers were thankful for the turnout for the ‚ÄòRide of Silence‚Äô and are hopeful to see the event grow in years to come.  Copyright 2023 KSFY. All rights reserved.

Haley Pullos was reportedly arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence after a crash in Pasadena.  ‚ÄúGeneral Hospital‚Äù star Haley Pullos was reportedly arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence after allegedly colliding with oncoming traffic on a freeway in Pasadena.  The 24-year-old actor was driving on the freeway April 29 when she allegedly swerved, cleared the dividing barrier and crashed into a car going the opposite direction at about 60 miles per hour, according to a police report obtained Wednesday by TMZ. The driver of the other car reportedly survived the crash but was hospitalized with severe injuries.  Firefighters reportedly rescued Pullos from her car and placed her in an ambulance, where she allegedly struck a firefighter who was assessing her injuries and shouted, ‚ÄúThis is a $400 f‚Äî shirt!‚Äù  Advertisement  California UFC veteran Tony Ferguson arrested on suspicion of DUI in Hollywood The former interim lightweight UFC champion was driving in Hollywood when his truck hit at least two other vehicles and flipped over, the LAPD said. No one was hurt.  Officers arrested Pullos at the hospital, where she was sedated after allegedly becoming hostile and violent toward healthcare workers, according to TMZ.  The case file reportedly noted that Pullos‚Äô breath smelled of alcohol and her speech was slurred. Officers also allegedly discovered edible cannabis products and mini-bottles of tequila in Pullos‚Äô vehicle, according to TMZ. The Times has reached out to the California Highway Patrol for additional information.  Police told TMZ that Pullos was involved in a hit-and-run traffic collision before the freeway accident.  Last week, Soap Opera Digest reported that ‚ÄúGeneral Hospital‚Äù had temporarily recast Pullos‚Äô character, Molly Lansing-Davis, while the actor is on medical leave. The show has reportedly tapped Holiday Mia Kriegel to sub in starting next week.  ‚ÄúUnfortunately, I was involved in an automobile accident and I‚Äôm doing okay, but I am going to need a little time to recover,‚Äù Pullos told Soap Opera Digest in a statement. ‚ÄúI will be back as soon as possible!‚Äù  Representatives for Pullos and ‚ÄúGeneral Hospital‚Äù did not immediately respond Wednesday to inquiries from The Times.

Victim identified in fatal Pearl River County accident  On Wednesday, May 17, 2023, at approximately 2 a.m, the Mississippi Highway Patrol responded to a fatal crash on Highway 26, near J M Tynes Road, in Pearl River County.  A 2007 GMC Truck driven by 19-year-old Silas Ensign of Laurel, MS, traveled West on Highway 26 when it collided with a 2022 Chevrolet Camaro driven by 27-year-old Nicholas Gagliano, of Ponchatoula, LA, traveling East on Highway 26. Both vehicles caught fire after the collision.  Nicholas Gagliano received fatal injuries from the crash and was pronounced dead on the scene.

GADSDEN COUNTY, Fla. (WTXL) ‚Äî The Florida Highway Patrol is responding to multiple accidents on Interstate 10 westbound in Gadsden County Wednesday afternoon.  According to FHP, it responded to the accident near mile marker 184, which west of the I-10 exit to the city of Midway (U.S. 90), at 3:24 p.m. Wednesday.  FHP said the incident involved two vehicles. A person died in the incident, but it is undetermined at this time what vehicle the person who died was operating.  A second and separate incident occurred less than 500 feet from the initial accident as the Florida Highway Patrol said minor injuries were sustained in the second accident.  Lanes are blocked near the site of the first accident as westbound traffic delays on I-10 extend back near the Gadsden/Leon County line.  Multiple law enforcement officials are assisting as traffic westbound has been diverted to exit 192 in Midway, which is U.S. 90 (Blue Star Highway).

Atascosa County Sheriff David Soward identified the man as 64-year-old Able Calvillo from Charlotte, Texas.  Example video title will go here for this video  SAN ANTONIO ‚Äî A man died in a mining accident in Atascosa County, officials said Wednesday.  The man's body was found at the work site after he went missing around 1 a.m. Wednesday. After hours of searching, the Atascosa County Sheriff's Office, along with the Jourdanton Fire Department, were called out to assist around 4 a.m.  Atascosa County Sheriff David Soward identified the man as 64-year-old Abel Calvillo from Charlotte, Texas. Sheriff Soward said Calvillo was operating a bulldozer when a wall saturated by the rain collapsed over the machine, smothering Calvillo. Rescue crews used drone technology to try to find him via thermal heat, but his body was not found until 5 a.m. Wednesday.  Officials say he possibly suffocated or drowned from the mud and dirt covering him.  Sheriff Soward said the mining site is owned by North American Construction Company. KENS 5 spoke with a staff member of the company who did confirm there was an incident, but did not give any other details.  The Mine Safety and Health Administration is investigating. The KENS 5 News team focuses on stories that really matter to our community.

COLUMBIA, S.C. ‚Äî One person is dead after a single car accident on Garners Ferry Road on Wednesday evening.  According to Lance Cpl. Tyler Tidwell with the South Carolina Highway Patrol (SCHP), the accident happened a little after 6 p.m. on Garners Ferry Road, just a few miles from Piney Branch Road.  Tidwell says a 2009 Honda Civic was traveling west on Garners Ferry Road when it went off the left side of the road and overturned.  The driver, identified by Richland County Coroner Naida Rutherford as Totheyona N. Brown, 30, of Sumter, was pronounced dead at the scene.

HARRISBURG, Pa. (WHTM) ‚Äî A 61-year-old man is being charged for his alleged role in the death of a woman who was hit by a vehicle in December 2022, according to Harrisburg Police.  Harrisburg Police say Eddie Rushin was driving near Cameron and Market Streets on Dec. 8, 2022, when he allegedly hit a man and a woman who were crossing Cameron Street. The woman was taken to a local hospital but died due to her injuries, according to a police report.  Police did not provide updates on the man who was also hit. Police allege that Rushin was under the influence of a controlled substance and driving at high speeds when the accident happened. SALT LAKE CITY ‚Äî One of Salt Lake City's most popular restaurants has once again opened its doors after being closed for months due to heavy water damage.  Manoli's chef and owner, Manoli Katsaneva, shared the story on what shuttered his restaurant since December because of an accident in the business upstairs. He said a quarter-inch pipe came undone from a water cooler, letting out gallons of water for hours overnight.  "It was just raining through the ceiling," he explained, "there was water going through all of the drywall, all over the floor, the equipment, the floors, the tables. Then it went through our basement level, so it just completely kind of destroyed the entire restaurant."  Katsanevas says damage costs have already topped $200,000 with the possibility of more to come. Without insurance, he doesn't know if his Manoli's would have recovered. And the damage couldn't have come at a worse time as the restaurant had just been nominated for a prestigious hospitality award.  "We got nominated for James Beard [Award] which is amazing, it's like the Oscar for restaurants and obviously we were elated to have it; it would've been awesome if we were open when we had it because I'm sure it would've boosted our business," Katsanevas said.  Manoli's was also expecting to be the food destination during NBA All-Star Weekend. When that all came to a halt, Manoli's still found a way to make some things happen during the closure.  "We were already contracted out by the NBA, so because of that we rented out a commissary kitchen and we still catered for three days straight, 8 hours a day over at the Hyatt for all the NBA All-Stars," the owner said.  On Tuesday, Manoli's was finally able to open its doors and allow customers to smell and taste what the owner himself describes as modern Greek food.  "We're only a 50-seat restaurant. We did over 100 covers last night and they were all regulars that have been coming here for the eight years we've been open," Katsanevas said. "It was just so cool to be able to see everyone again and hug everyone and say hi. It was probably one of the coolest services we ever worked."

A Good Samaritan who stopped to help the victims of an accident inadvertently set the stage for a wreck that killed two people and seriously injured three others.  It happened about 2 a.m. Sunday on U.S. 287 just west of Wichita Falls.  According to a report from the Department of Public Safety:  A Chevy Tahoe had been involved in a wreck and was disabled in the northbound lanes. The driver of a northbound Chevy Suburban stopped on the shoulder to help. The driver of a northbound 18-wheeler saw the parked suburban and steered to the left to give it space, but struck the Tahoe.  Two men in the Tahoe were thrown from their vehicle and died at the scene. They were identified as Francisco Sanchez Sustaita, 45, and Rocio Rodriguez Hernandez, 43. Both men were from Chillicothe.  The driver of the Suburban who stopped to help is John Michael Christopherson, 24, of Midlothian. He was listed in stable condition.  The driver of the 18-wheeler is Rodney Mitchell Cary, 68, of Irving. His passenger was Holliday resident John Evan Poore, 59. Both men are listed in stable condition.  The DPS said wet roads and poor visibility contributed to the accident. The highway was closed for several hours as DPS investigated and the wreckage was cleared away.  Wichita County deputies and Wichita Falls Police were at the scene, which happened just on the outskirts of the city.

A 14-year-old girl was killed after being ejected from a car as it slammed into the back of a parked UPS truck in Queens.  SPRINGFIELD GARDENS, Queens (WABC) -- A 14-year-old girl was killed after being ejected from a car as it slammed into the back of a parked UPS truck in Queens.  Police are investigating why a 16-year-old boy was behind the wheel with another minor. The NYPD says he was driving with a Learner's Permit and speeding.  "As a mother, a mother don't want to go through this. I found her bracelet I can't sleep. I come to get her. I come to get my daughter," said Keisha Francis, the victim's mother.  Francis searched desperately through the broken glass Thursday morning for something, anything that would remind her of her 14-year-old daughter, Fortune Williams.  A bracelet was all that was left after the deadly crash.  "I have three children and she showed me more love than anything else. At night I have to cuddle with Fortune, I couldn't sleep last night. I can't live without my daughter," Francis said.  Fortune was a passenger in the red BMW. Eyewitness News has obtained video but stopped it before it shows the car barreling into the back of a parked UPS truck.  The impact knocked the delivery driver to the ground.  "The car was coming basically maybe 90-100 mph," a witness said.  An eyewitness says the 16-year-old driver of the BMW was tailing a tractor-trailer on North Conduit Avenue Wednesday around 6:45 p.m. when he tried to switch lanes and lost control.  Police, who set up a speed trap a day later, say the teen driver was going at high rate of speed.  The driver survived but Fortune was thrown from the BMW upon impact. She was a student at Springfield Gardens high school and interested in the medical field.  Her life was cut far too short, leaving her mother forever with a void.  "My life will never be the same without Fortune. Fortune is a sweetheart. She's a loving, caring child," Francis said.  Her mother says she was working a double shift the night of this tragedy. Fortune was home with her older sister, but went outside to hang out in her friend's car. Sadly, she never came home.  The 16-year-old driver of the car was taken to Cohen Children's Medical Center where he is stable. A single-vehicle accident near McDowell on Friday claimed the life of an Odell woman, according to news releases from the Livingston County Coroner's office and the Sheriff's Department.  The releases state that a call was received at 11:39 a.m. on May 11 regarding the accident taking place on 1300 North Road near 1700 East Road. This places the scene southeast of McDowell. The releases also state that Jessica Casey, 33, of Odell died at the scene. According to Coroner Dan Watson, ‚ÄúIt appears that Jessica was West bound on 1300 North Road and lost control and ended up in the north ditch.‚Äù  The Sheriff's Department release added that the vehicle had overturned and ended up in a creek.  Watson said that Casey was pronounced dead at the scene by Deputy Coroner Shelly Lewis. Watson has order an autopsy.  Both news releases state that the Sheriff's Department, Pontiac Fire and EMS, and SELCAS responded to the scene.  The accident remains under investigation by the Livingston County Sheriff's Department and the Coroner's office.

The Johnson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office is investigating a single-vehicle fatal accident near Edinburgh.  A box truck went off the road near County Road 800 East and County Road 650 South Wednesday afternoon at around 5:14 p.m. The driver was going southbound when the truck went off the roadway and down a steep embankment, said Sheriff Duane Burgess.  While off the road, the vehicle hit several trees and caught fire, he said.  County Road 800 East from (Johnson) County Road 650 South to (Shelby) County Road 1000 South will be closed for an undetermined amount of time as the accident is investigated and cleaned up, he said.  The Johnson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office is investigating with assistance from the Shelby County Sheriff‚Äôs Office and Edinburgh Police Department. The Amity, Edinburgh and Marietta fire departments also responded to the scene.  The accident began in Johnson County but the truck came to a rest in Shelby County, so the Shelby County Coroner‚Äôs Office will be conducting the investigation, Burgess said.  The accident is under investigation and more information, including the identity of the driver, will be released when possible.

Just like ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs Got Talent,‚Äù Simon Cowell keeps chugging along.  The famously critical judge from the hit NBC show broke his back in an accident while riding an electric bike in 2020, a moment that changed how he looks at things.  ‚ÄúIt was painful, it wasn‚Äôt great,‚Äù he told TODAY‚Äôs Jason Kennedy in an interview with fellow ‚ÄúAGT‚Äù stars Howie Mandel, Sofia Vergara, Heidi Klum and Terry Crews that aired May 17.  ‚ÄúHowever, I was so unfit before the accident. I didn‚Äôt know how unfit I was until I had to do all this stuff afterwards," he explained. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòMy God.‚Äô Things like that, I believe happened for a reason.‚Äù  Simon Cowell talks about the "painful" bike accident he was involved in back in 2020. TODAY  One thing the accident didn‚Äôt change, though, was his desire to ride a bike.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still gonna stay on my bike,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm obsessed with these things.‚Äù  Cowell, 63, had to undergo a six-hour surgery following his accident. Still, Cowell was grateful that he avoided a worse fate.  ‚ÄúIt could have been a lot worse. When I saw the X-ray, I really nearly smashed my spine to pieces, so I literally wouldn‚Äôt (have) been able to walk,‚Äù he told ‚ÄúExtra‚Äù in February 2021.  Cowell is now back and ready to go on the 18th season of ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs Got Talent.‚Äù It will be the fourth season that he teams up with Crews, Mandel, Vergara and Klum. And while Cowell made his name being a no-nonsense judge of talent, he and his ‚ÄúAGT‚Äù co-stars all get along famously.  ‚ÄúWhen we say we are a family it does actually feel that way because we like each other,‚Äù he said.  You can catch Cowell and the rest of the gang when the new season of ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs Got Talent‚Äù premieres May 30 at 8 p.m. ET on NBC.

NEW YORK -- An investigation is underway after a deadly accident at a train station on Staten Island.  Police say a 15-year-old boy was killed in a train accident in Eltingville.  Officers found the teen unconscious with a head injury after responding to a 911 call just after 1 p.m. Wednesday.  MTA Police say the boy was riding the train with friends when he climbed above the car by himself, hitting an overhead structure.  He was rushed to the hospital but died a short time later.  In a statement, NYC Transit President Richard Davey said, "This was an awful situation that demonstrates again the deadly risk taken by anyone who attempts to subway surf. Our hearts go out to loved ones who have senselessly lost a child and we continue to encourage teenagers find safer ways to seek thrills."

At approximately 1:40 p.m. on May 17, 2023, Port of Seattle Police and Fire were called to respond to a vehicle injury accident on the upper drive of SEA Airport. Upon arrival, it appeared to be an unintentional action with a red SUV accelerating on the sidewalk and striking three people near the north end of the upper drive. Those three people were sent to area hospitals with serious injuries.  The upper drive was closed completely for about an hour and a half until approximately 3:15 p.m., with lanes opened around the investigation area. Operations returned to normal about 5:30 p.m.  Port of Seattle Police (POSPD) is continuing its investigation.  POSPD is asking anyone who may have witnessed the accident to please contact 206-787-5401.

The widower groom of the newlywed killed by an alleged drunk driver on Folly Beach April 28 has filed a wrongful death civil lawsuit. It claims the driver, Jamie Komoroski of James Island, had been ‚Äúbar hopping‚Äù throughout the fateful day.  Charleston-based attorney Daniel Dalton of Mickelsen Dalton LLC is representing Aric Hutchinson, the groom who received multiple injuries in the golf cart-car accident that made national headlines.  Dalton  ‚ÄúThis case is about keeping the public safe from drunk driving,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve performed our own investigation into this matter. We‚Äôve been cooperating with law enforcement however we can, and we felt confident enough to be ready to file the lawsuit based on what we‚Äôve found out so far.‚Äù  The lawsuit follows a tragic accident in which the alleged drunk driver‚Äôs car collided with a golf cart transporting newlywed bride Samantha Miller and groom Hutchinson, as well as two others. The bride and groom had gotten married only hours earlier.  According to a news report, a lab report from the State Law Enforcement Division showed Komoroski had a blood-alcohol level of 0.26 at the time, more than three times over the legal limit.  Hutchinson is still physically recovering from injuries sustained in the crash, Dalton said. According to news reports, data retrieved from Komoroski‚Äôs rental car showed she was driving 65 mph, well over twice the speed limit.  Dalton said there are still facts and a lot of questions that hadn‚Äôt yet been answered.  ‚ÄúThere are still many details we don‚Äôt know about the sequence of events leading up to the tragic crash,‚Äù Dalton said. ‚ÄúBut by filing a lawsuit, we can begin the legal discovery process that allows us to get the answers that Samantha‚Äôs family deserves.‚Äù  According to the lawsuit, ‚ÄúDespite being noticeably and visibly intoxicated at each of these establishments, Jamie Komoroski continued to be served, provided, and/or allowed to consume alcohol in each of them.‚Äù  Dalton said video and photo evidence, as well as eyewitness testimony, were used in the investigation to ensure confidence in Komoroski‚Äôs level of intoxication described in the lawsuit.  Businesses named in the lawsuit were Beach Front Bars, Snapper Jacks, The Folly Beach Deli, The Drop In Bar & Deli, The Crab Shack, Folly Tacqueria, Taco Boy, El Gallo Bar and Grill, and Bottle Cap Management Group.  According to the lawsuit, these establishments ‚Äú ‚Ä¶ as licensed sellers of beer, wine and liquor for consumption pursuant to South Carolina law, had a duty to obey all laws and regulations regarding the sale of alcoholic beverages and exercise due care ‚Ä¶ not to allow patrons to become intoxicated, to not serve alcohol to intoxicated persons.‚Äù  The lawsuit also lists about 20 John and Jane Does representing owners, managers, operators, agents and more whose ‚Äúnegligence contributed to‚Äù Miller‚Äôs death.  The private investigation is ongoing, he said.  ‚ÄúWe hope that the bars will cooperate with us and provide whatever they have,‚Äù Dalton said. ‚ÄúI would think given the tragic nature of this case that they would want to own up to whatever happened or didn‚Äôt happen ‚Ä¶ we‚Äôve seen cooperation from some parties; others are tightening up a little bit.

SCHOHARIE, N.Y. ‚Äî It was a staggering and seemingly incomprehensible tragedy: a Saturday afternoon limo ride gone terribly wrong, leaving 20 people dead, including a large group of young friends and relatives headed to a birthday party.  On Wednesday, the operator of the company that rented out that vehicle ‚Äî a 31-foot-long, five-ton 2001 Ford Excursion stretch limousine ‚Äî was found guilty on 20 counts of second-degree manslaughter in the October 2018 accident.  The operator, Nauman Hussain, could face up to 15 years in prison when he is sentenced on May 31.  The verdict, announced to an emotionally charged courtroom and after less than a day of deliberation by a jury in Schoharie County, west of Albany, caps a nearly five-year ordeal for the families of the victims, which included all 17 passengers, the driver and two pedestrians outside a cafe and store in Schoharie, N.Y.  A 2020 report by the National Transportation Safety Board found that the limousine‚Äôs brake system failed on Route 30 outside Schoharie, causing the vehicle to career down a long hill to the valley below, eventually reaching more than 100 m.p.h., flying toward an intersection with another busy rural byway.

Two members of the Karahanlƒ± family were killed in a traffic accident on Monday while driving to Turkey‚Äôs central province of Kƒ±rƒ±kkale to visit Uƒüur Karahanlƒ±, who was jailed over alleged links to the G√ºlen movement, a faith-based group accused by the government of ‚Äúterrorist‚Äù activities, the Bold Medya news website reported.  Uƒüur Karahanlƒ±‚Äôs father and mother died shortly before first responders arrived on the scene, while his wife was seriously injured in the accident.  According to local reports, Karahanlƒ±, a former teacher who was dismissed by a government decree as part of purges that followed a July 15, 2016 coup attempt, was in 2021 sentenced to six-and-a-half years in prison on conviction of alleged links to the movement.  Karahanlƒ± had previously been jailed in a prison in southern Hatay province, one of the areas hardest hit by two powerful earthquakes in early February, after which he was transferred to the prison in central Turkey.  Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan has been targeting followers of the G√ºlen movement, inspired by Turkish Muslim cleric Fethullah G√ºlen, since the corruption investigations of December 17-25, 2013, which implicated then-prime minister Erdoƒüan, his family members and his inner circle.  Dismissing the investigations as a G√ºlenist coup and conspiracy against his government, Erdoƒüan designated the movement as a terrorist organization and began to target its members. He intensified the crackdown on the movement after the abortive putsch in 2016, which he accused G√ºlen of masterminding. G√ºlen and the movement strongly deny involvement in the coup attempt or any terrorist activity.  Following the failed coup, the Turkish government declared a state of emergency and carried out a massive purge of state institutions under the pretext of an anti-coup fight.  More than 130,000 public servants, including 4,156 judges and prosecutors, as well as 24,706 members of the armed forces were summarily removed from their jobs for alleged membership in or relationships with ‚Äúterrorist organizations‚Äù by emergency decree-laws subject to neither judicial nor parliamentary scrutiny.  Former public servants were not only fired from their jobs; they were also banned from working again in the public sector and getting a passport. The government also made it difficult for them to work formally in the private sector. Notes were put on the social security database about dismissed public servants to deter potential employers, leading them to work in unskilled jobs with little workplace safety. There have been a number of cases in which former public servants died in occupational accidents.

Tim Slachta, of Garnet Valley, died Wednesday, May 10 while jumping over Monroe Township.  A seasoned jumper, Slachta leaves behind is wife, Sue, and their two boys.  More than $2,800 had been raised as of Tuesday, May 16 on a GoFundMe for the family, launched by Slachta's friends.  "Tim was a hallmark at Duffers Pub, Glen mills," the campaign reads. "Traveling was one of his many hobbies as well as outdoor sports with his sons. He passed on his love of winter sports to Kevin and TJ.  "Sue and the boys are now struggling with an immense and unimaginable loss that has shaken their world to the core. His sons are now having to navigate life without a father and struggling to cope with such a loss at only 16 years old."  Click here to donate. Flowers are placed on a walkway near where the raft capsized, in Minakami, Gunma Prefecture, on May 9, 2023. (Mainichi/Ryutaro Nishimoto)  MAEBASHI -- The parents of a 19-year-old university student who died in a recent rafting accident on the Tone River in Gunma Prefecture are seeking answers after he was found without a life jacket, and it emerged a guide on another boat had said the student's raft would capsize.  The victim, Keisuke Honda, had only just entered a national university in Tokyo, and on the day of the accident, he left his family home early in the morning. "I had no idea that he was going rafting," his mother said. His father added, "I thought he was going on a day trip with friends and that he would come back as normal."  At around 6:45 p.m. on May 5, the parents received a call from Gunma Prefecture Police's Numata Police Station, informing them of the accident. They went by car to Gunma, arriving at about 9 p.m. It was dark and they couldn't see any rescue boats out.  "Is no one looking for our son?" they wondered in shock. The parents took out a flashlight they had bought on the way and made their way through the grass at the side of the river.  "I thought that if he was in water as cold as this, I wanted to rescue him quickly," the father said. Multiple cuts ran up his arms, apparently made by the grass.  Son found with no life jacket  The teen's parents spent seven hours searching a roughly 1 kilometer stretch of the river starting from the accident site, but didn't find anything. Police resumed their search at 5 a.m. on May 6, and at 5:49 a.m. they found him about 300 meters downstream from the Suwakyo Bridge over the Tone River. The cause of death was drowning. He was not wearing a life jacket.  The parents met with officials from the rafting tour company at Numata Police Station on May 6, and spoke with them for about an hour. They asked about the situation at the time their son's raft capsized and about rescue efforts immediately afterward, but said they didn't receive a concrete explanation. "They didn't tell us anything," the student's father recalled angrily.  Their distrust grew after they heard about conditions at the time of the accident from a man in another rafting boat, who took part in the same tour.  According to the man, the participants were in three boats, with two full of families with children, and a blue one carrying Honda and his friends. The man said that when he got into his boat, the guide said, "That blue boat is going to capsize." The other boats passed the accident site safely and then waited for the blue boat, and again the guide said that Honda's boat would capsize.  After the accident, the other two rafts were taken to the side of the river and the tour ended partway through. Participants were reportedly handed commemorative photos at this point, taken by a photographer who was following the boats in a vehicle along the river. The man said he wanted Honda's parents to know the river conditions at the time, and handed his photos to them, and also told them about what he saw.  Rocks and driftwood are seen scattered about at the scene of the accident as water splashes up, on the Tone River in Minakami, Gunma Prefecture, on May 9, 2023. (Mainichi/Ryutaro Nishimoto)  The photos showed Honda wearing a life jacket and a helmet, shoulder to shoulder with his friends, and showed him laughing as water splashed above the raft.  His mother said, "It was a dangerous activity. He was suddenly thrown out into water chilly with snowmelt, and his life jacket was carried downstream, so he must have sunk into the water around where the boat capsized. The tour guide's rescue effort wasn't enough at all. I want the police to conduct a proper investigation."  Operating company: 'A turn of events we can't take back'  The president of the company that organized the tour commented, "I'm truly sorry that there has been a turn of events we can't take back. We will consider efforts to prevent a recurrence and think about how to atone for this."  According to the president, participants sign consent forms acknowledging that if they fall out of the boat and stand up the current, their legs could get pinned against rocks and they could suffer broken bones or even drown. Verbal explanations were also given to make people aware of the risks.  On the possibility of a boat capsizing, the company president said, there were times when people played balancing games, standing on the edge of the boat and that the boats would sometimes capsize as a result. But people don't do that in the current season when there is a lot of water in the river and the temperature is cold.  Regarding the comment from the passenger on the other boat that their guide had said that the blue boat would capsize, the president said, "When two boats have gone ahead and are waiting, we sometimes humorously explain that we will help the other one in such and such a way if they capsize."  According to Outdoor Joint Association Minakami, an organization of Gunma Prefecture-based rafting companies, safety checks are conducted along the Tone River five times a year, and if tour guides find anything abnormal, they are required to quickly report it to the association. Each operator is also certified in whitewater rescue and first aid. Association director Mitsuyoshi Ishikawa commented, "If something happens, we respond quickly. We've established fairly strict safety standards."  A total of four people died in Tone River rafting accidents in Gunma Prefecture between 2000 and 2002 -- two male and one female passenger in their 20s and 30s and one male guide in his 20s.  Water safety group chairman: 'Wear your life jacket properly'  Hidetoshi Saito, chairman of the Society of Water Rescue and Survival Research and a graduate school professor at the Nagaoka University of Technology in Niigata Prefecture, commented, "People need to be aware that boats can sink or capsize. That's not to say that we shouldn't get into them; rather I want people to wear life jackets properly so they can enjoy the ride."  In the event of an accident such as a boat capsizing, it is important to float on the water to ensure one can breathe. According to Saito, life jackets can come off easily if only the zipper is closed, so the belt and buckle need to be fastened tighter than people might expect. He says that if the belt and buckle hadn't come undone, then the student may have slipped out of the life jacket, but if there were undone, then there is a possibility he either wasn't wearing it properly or had undone it himself before drowning. "If he wasn't wearing it properly from the start then the operator would be held responsible," he said.  (Japanese original by Azusa Hinata and Ryutaro Nishimoto, Maebashi Bureau)

Safety is a concern at Atlanta City Hall amid eleven heavy truck accidents in one month.  Atlanta Public Works crews were involved in those crashes.  In some of those, Director Al Wiggins said other drivers simply get too close to the vehicles, not leaving enough room for sanitation workers to collect the trash.  Wiggins, in a report to Atlanta City Council members, said he recently joined the workers on the road for a closer look at the issue.  "I can tell you, it is a dangerous job they perform," Wiggins said. "On more than one occasion, we had some near misses."  Recent data shows a total of seven accidents in January and February. But in March, crews were involved in eleven mishaps. That is one every three day.  "We have got to get that down," Wiggins said.  Image 1 of 20 ‚ñº A new report made to the Atlanta City Council shows at least 11 accidents happened in one month involving public works‚Äô vehicles. (FOX 5)  The commissioner does not put all the blame on drivers who are not yielding.  "We can do a better job. Slow down," Wiggins said.  He has added an emergency preparedness chief to the staff who is tasked with analyzing the sanitation routes for "hot spots."

A 44-year-old Mosinee man is dead after a farming accident in the town of Bergen on Friday afternoon.  According to a police report, At 3:13 p.m. police were dispatched to a farm in the 139000 block on Moon Road in the township of Bergen for a medical emergency. The man's father called and said his son was in the silo attached to the barn and the silo motor had fallen and pinned him.  Scott Tryba, 44, was found dead by his brother. According to a police report, the man's brother came in from tilling the fields and noticed the cows hadn't been milked yet. He said his brother "hadn't missed a day of milking cows in 44 years."  In Tryba's obituary it says: "Scott was a proud farmer who loved his Brown Swiss and all that farming entailed. He loved the outdoors, hunting, John Deere, the smell of fresh country air, and taking great care of the land entrusted to him and the animals that dwelled it. He was our north, south, east and west. Our working week and Sunday rest. Scott was the friend we all needed and will be forever missed."  The report also said:  He knew he was up in the silo shoveling sileage at 12:30 p.m. He went up to look for his brother and noticed the silage motor had fallen on his back.  When police arrived, the man was pronounced dead. It appeared the wire snapped, and the motor fell approximately 50 feet and pinned Tyrba.  After investigating, the death has been deemed non-suspicious, according to the report.

The accident took place during the construction of a drainage system within the mine. Credit: JavierLJ/Shutterstock.com.  Chinese mining company Zijin Mining has reported a mining accident at one of its mines in Tibet, the circumstances of which have led to the stopping of production.  On 14 May, a lift cage fell during shaft construction in the drainage system at the Julong open-pit copper and polymetallic mine, cutting contact with six workers.  Zijin has suspended mining production at the site and launched search and rescue operations for the missing workers.  The company added that it has carried out an investigation and rectification of the hidden risks. The cause of the accident is still being investigated.  The construction of the Julong mine was subcontracted to Fujian Xingwanxiang Construction Group by Zijin subsidiary Tibet Julong Copper.  Zijin owns a 50.1% stake in the Julong mine, which produced 115,000 tonnes (t) of copper last year and is planning to increase its production to 152,000t this year.  Phase one production at Julong Copper began in December 2021. Located in the Tibetan plateau at an altitude between 4,000m and 5,000m, the mine features 10.7 million tonnes of copper and 570,000t of molybdenum.  Last month, the company through Barrick Gold, a joint venture with Barrick Niugini (BNL), entered a New Porgera Progress Agreement (NPPA) with the Papua New Guinea Government.  According to the NPPA, all three parties ‚Äì Zijin, BNL and the Papua New Guinea Government ‚Äì have agreed to reopen the Porgera Gold Mine at the earliest opportunity.  Operations at the mine were suspended in April 2020 due to the failure to secure approval for its extension. The NPPA signing is an important milestone in resuming operations.

John Badman|The Telegraph  ALTON ‚Äî A smashed Jeep Cherokee came to rest on a median Monday afternoon after it collided with a full size Dodge pickup truck on Alby Street at West Center Drive, sending one person to a local hospital.  The crash occurred at about 2 p.m., with one of the occupants transported by Alton Fire Department ambulance with non life-threatening injuries.

UAE: 2 Emiratis killed in horrific accident in multi-vehicle collision  Incident took place in an intersection when two vehicles collided with an overloaded truck  By Web Desk Published: Wed 17 May 2023, 7:28 AM Last updated: Wed 17 May 2023, 10:37 PM  In a tragic road accident on Tuesday, May 16, a 17-year-old Emirati male and a 44-year-old female citizen lost their lives in a multi-vehicle collision. Two other individuals sustained injuries ranging from serious to moderate.  The accident took place in an intersection (crossing road) towards the port of Fujairah when two vehicles collided with a truck. The officials from the Fujairah Police General Command reached the location immediately after receiving the information and were able to rescue the other passengers.  According to Emarat AlYoum report, preliminary investigations revealed that the Arab truck driver was driving an overloaded vehicle. It was also found that the driver exceeded the permissible speed limit, which led to the loss of control and subsequent collision with the two cars.  Civil Defence teams swiftly extinguished the fire that erupted due to the accident. They successfully extricated those passengers trapped inside the burning vehicle. The truck driver and the driver of one of the vehicles were transported to the hospital by the national ambulance. However, the young man who was accompanied by his father in the first vehicle succumbed to his injuries, along with the woman in the other vehicle.  Fujairah Police have warned about the dangerous consequences of driving heavy vehicles at speeds exceeding the permitted limits on both internal and external roads. They emphasised that such reckless driving often compromises the driver's ability to control their vehicle effectively, particularly in emergencies.  ALSO READ:

PM Modi expresses grief after 9 killed in road accident in UP‚Äôs Fatehpur  Prime Minister Narendra Modi has expressed grief over the loss of lives due to a road accident in Fatehpur district of Uttar Pradesh in which nine people died after a speeding tanker hit an auto at Jahanabad in Uttar Pradesh‚Äôs Fatehpur district.    Fatehpur: May 17 (IANS) Prime Minister Narendra Modi has expressed grief over the loss of lives due to a road accident in Fatehpur district of Uttar Pradesh in which nine people died after a speeding tanker hit an auto at Jahanabad in Uttar Pradesh‚Äôs Fatehpur district.  The PRO of Fatehpur Superintendent of Police, Rajesh Kumar Singh, said that several people were coming to Jahanabad in Fatehpur district in an autorickshaw from a wedding procession near Chilli Mod.  On the way, a speeding milk tanker hit the autorickshaw near Chilli Mod under Jahanabad police station area. Nine people travelling in the auto rickshaw were killed while several others were seriously injured in this accident.  The Fatehpur SP added that the post-mortem of all deceased people in the accident is being done who hail from different places in the district. The driver of the milk tanker ran away with his vehicle after the accident, but he has been nabbed and legal action is being taken against him.  Expressing grief over the accident, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday tweeted: ‚ÄúThe road accident in Uttar Pradesh‚Äôs Fatehpur is extremely sad. My deepest condolences to those who have lost their families in this tragedy. Along with this, I wish the injured to recover soon. Under the supervision of the state government, the local administration is fully committed in helping the victims.‚Äù  He said that the next of kin of each of the deceased would be given a financial compensation of Rs two lakh each from the Prime Minister‚Äôs National Relief Fund, while each of the injured would be given Rs 50,000.  Expressing grief over the road mishap, Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said on Tuesday, ‚ÄúThe loss of lives in the Fatehpur road accident is extremely sad. My condolences are with the bereaved families. District administration officials have been given instructions for immediate treatment of the injured. I pray to Shri Ram that the deceased rest in peace and give speedy recovery to the injured.‚Äù  State BJP President Bhupendra Chowdhary said, ‚ÄúThe news of many casualties in the road accident under Jahanabad police station area of Fatehpur district is extremely sad. The government has given instructions to the administrative officers of the district for proper treatment of the injured. May God give strength to the families of the deceased and provide speedy recovery to those injured in the accident.‚Äù  Like this: Like Loading...

Assam Police Sub-Inspector (SI) Junmoni Rabha died in a horrific road accident at Jakhalabandha area in Assam‚Äôs Nagaon district on Tuesday (May 16) at around 2 am.  As per reports, Rabha‚Äôs car lost control and collided with a truck bearing registration number UP 78UT 4518 near Sarubhagia Village on NH 37.  Soon after the incident, local police reached the spot and rushed Rabha to Kaliabor Sub-Divisional Civil Hospital for medical attention where doctors declared her dead on arrival.  Reportedly, Junmoni Rabha, who was posted at Morikolong police station in Nagaon district, was driving towards Jorhat in civil clothes at around 2 am when her vehicle rammed into the truck.  Meanwhile, Rabha‚Äôs body has been sent to Nagaon for post-mortem.  Junmoni Rabha was a SI at Morakolong police station in Nagaon who made headlines last year for various controversies she was embroiled in ‚Äì including corruption, criminal conspiracy, and cheating, for which was also arrested. She was later granted bail by a session‚Äôs court.

Mariappan Subramanian, who worked as a Test Lead with HCL Technologies, according to his LinkedIn profile, died on Monday at Hillsborough County in Tampa.  The car which struck him had jumped a red light, according to a fundraiser page. Mariappan is survived by his wife and their four-year-old son who are living in India. Jersey City, NJ (May 15, 2023) ‚Äì According to the Hudson County Prosecutor‚Äôs Office, police are looking into a fatal collision that occurred in Jersey City early Monday morning, May 15.  The accident reportedly took place around 2:30 a.m. on Monday morning. The intersection of Kennedy Boulevard and St. Pauls Avenue was closed due to the accident, per officers from the Jersey City Police Department.  Authorities said that cops located a totally engulfed vehicle on the northern shoulder of the highway. The driver, a man in his twenties from Jersey City, was fatally injured and pronounced dead at the scene. It‚Äôs unclear if any other victims were hurt in the incident.  It was initially unclear what caused the collision, though the investigation into the accident remains ongoing at this time. Any witnesses to the crash were asked to contact the Jersey City PD immediately.  Our deepest condolences go out to the deceased man‚Äôs family. Our thoughts are with any injured victims and their families in hopes of a full recovery.
