When you‚Äôve been in a car accident, there is no doubt the situation can be incredibly stressful and overwhelming. After making sure everyone is safe and getting medical attention if necessary, many individuals find themselves wondering what else needs to be done or what rights they may have under the law.  To help sort out this legal process of a car accident case and know what information will be relevant during such proceedings, here are some key points to keep in mind for both women and men.  How to File a Claim After an Accident  Filing a claim after an accident can be a complicated and time-consuming process, but it is essential to ensure that you receive the compensation you deserve. Whether you were involved in a car accident, slip and fall, or any other type of incident, it‚Äôs crucial to seek legal advice right away to understand your rights and responsibilities.  You will need to gather evidence, such as photographs, witness statements, and medical records, to support your claim. It‚Äôs important to remember that insurance companies may try to offer you a settlement that is not in your best interest, so having an experienced attorney in your corner can help you navigate the claim process and negotiate a fair settlement. Don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to a legal professional for assistance in filing your claim and protecting your rights.  Getting legal advice  The legal process for a car accident case can be complex, so it is always in your best interest to get legal advice as soon as possible. An experienced attorney will help you understand the laws that apply to your situation and provide sound legal advice on how to proceed with your claim. Whether you decide to get advice from youraccidentattorneys.com, or research to find a suitable attorney, make sure you are getting assistance from a qualified professional. When you are represented by a qualified attorney, you will be able to rest assured that your claim is in capable hands and that your rights are being appropriately protected.  Types of Damages You Can Seek in a Car Accident Case  In car accident cases, the types of damages that can be sought can vary greatly depending on the circumstances of the incident. The most common types of damages that plaintiffs may seek include compensation for medical expenses, lost wages, property damage, and pain and suffering.  However, there are other damages that may also be applicable, such as punitive damages, which are intended to punish a defendant for particularly egregious behavior. It is important to work with an experienced attorney who can guide you through the legal process and help you pursue the appropriate damages for your case. Don‚Äôt hesitate to seek legal advice if you‚Äôve been involved in a car accident and believe you deserve compensation for any losses or injuries suffered.  Proving Fault in a Car Accident Case  When it comes to car accident cases, proving fault can be a complex process that often ends up in court. Legal professionals and insurance companies will examine a variety of factors, including police reports, witness statements, and medical evidence to determine who is at fault for the accident. It is important to remember that proving fault is not simply about assigning blame, but rather about providing justice and ensuring that the responsible party is held accountable for their actions. Therefore, if you are involved in a car accident, it is crucial to seek legal representation to ensure that your rights are upheld and the responsible party is brought to justice.  Common Defense Strategies Used in Car Accident Cases  When it comes to car accident cases, common defense strategies are often employed in an effort to minimize or eliminate liability. One such strategy involves arguing that the plaintiff was partially or completely at fault for the accident. Another common defense tactic is to challenge the plaintiff‚Äôs claims of injury or damages, often by questioning the severity of the injuries or the validity of the medical treatment received. Moreover, defendants may attempt to settle the case for a smaller amount by arguing that the plaintiff had pre-existing injuries or conditions that were aggravated by the accident. It is important to work with an experienced attorney who can help navigate these defense strategies and fight for your rights in court.  Timeline of the Legal Process for a Car Accident Case  When you‚Äôve been in a car accident, the legal process can seem daunting and complicated. However, it‚Äôs important to understand the timeline of events that will unfold. The process typically begins with filing a claim with your insurance company, followed by an investigation into the accident and determining who is at fault.  From there, negotiations may take place to reach a settlement. If a settlement cannot be reached, the case will proceed to court where a judge or jury will ultimately determine the outcome. It‚Äôs important to have a knowledgeable and experienced legal team on your side to guide you through each step of the process and ensure that your rights are protected.  The legal process of a car accident case can be a painstaking one requiring effort from all parties involved in order to satisfactorily resolve the dispute. It is vital for those who are involved in an accident to understand their rights and the steps they can take toward seeking the damages they deserve. Knowing who is at fault for an accident, what types of damages you can recover, and having a timeline for the progression of your case will help ensure that proceedings move quickly and efficiently. With this knowledge in hand, each party can work together to ensure a swift resolution in their car accident case.

Bermudian footballer Marco Warren is being remembered by his family, friends and members of the footballing community after he was identified as the victim of Sunday‚Äôs fatal hit and run accident.  Warren,29, was walking along the junction of Trinity Church Road and North Shore Road between 2 am and 3:15 am when he was struck by a car.  His death took Bermuda‚Äôs road fatality toll for 2023 to five.  In a social media post, the Bermuda Football Association (BFA) said it ‚Äújoins the Warren and Bermuda football family in mourning the loss of a rising icon of the beautiful game, Marco Warren, who had his debut international cap for Bermuda in March 2015 against Nicaragua. The match resulted in a 2-0 victory for our Gombey Warriors.  ‚ÄúBFA extends its heartfelt condolences to Marco‚Äôs family, friends, teammates, and fans. Our logo will be displayed in black until Marco‚Äôs funeral‚Äù.  Warren‚Äôs club, the PHC Zebras, also paid tribute to him saying they will never forget the impact that their star player had on the team and Bermuda.  ‚ÄúMarco was more than just a player. He was a part of our family, embodied the Zebra spirit, and was the heart of our team. Marco continually left fans in awe of his skills and inspired other players to improve. He was a humble person despite his level of greatness. When he was on the field, the ‚Äúmagician‚Äù just went to work,‚Äù the club said.  ‚ÄúMarco was a loving father, son, brother, boyfriend, nephew, cousin, teammate, and true friend. He was a leader both on and off the field as he demonstrated the well-rounded individual we aspire to develop for our community. All who encountered him were impressed with his wisdom and kindness.‚Äù  Bermudian star and Bristol City player Nahki Wells also remembered his teammate on Instagram.  Photo: @nahkiwells on Instagram  Wells posted a photo of him and Warren celebrating during a match.  Anyone with information that could solve this incident is urged to contact Police Constable Deforest Evans at 717-0860 or by e-mail at devans@bps.bm. Over 160 Edmonton pedestrians are injured in car accidents every year. Nearly five of those collisions turn out fatal. These kinds of accidents can lead to life-changing disabilities and catastrophic financial losses. You might lose work hours, incur thousands of medical bills, and experience severe trauma. If you or a loved one has been injured in an accident, consult Edmonton pedestrian accident lawyers who can help you overcome all three challenges. However, you can take a few steps at the accident spot to solidify your legal claim.  1) Call for Medical Assistance  Your health is the most important consideration after a collision. Severe injuries don‚Äôt always make themselves known straight away. Shock can mask pain, so getting an assessment from a qualified healthcare provider is crucial. That said, this is when the evidence is at its best, so contact local law enforcement as soon as you‚Äôve called for medical assistance. If your injuries are too severe to gather photographs and numbers, police presence at the scene will bolster your case.  An emergency room assessment is one of the most powerful things you can do to prove your damages. The sooner you see a doctor, the more convincing your evidence will be. Remember that personal injury cases draw more compensation when there‚Äôs solid diagnostic evidence, so X-rays and the like are key.  2) Gather Contact Information  Eyewitnesses disperse quickly. If your injuries aren‚Äôt life-threatening, exchanging information with everyone involved in the collision is essential. If there are eyewitnesses in sight, gather their contact details as well. You should also collect the insurance details of the at-fault party. While the police will gather their evidence, you should also take your photographs. If you see skid marks, car dents, or any other forms of damage, assume that an expert could use them to prove the cause of the accident. Make sure you snap the scene from different angles. You can‚Äôt take too many photographs, but you can certainly take too few.  3) Don‚Äôt Admit Guilt  Admitting guilt to eyewitnesses and at-fault parties can weaken your case, so avoid any comments that could be interpreted this way. Don‚Äôt apologize or express a sense of guilt. It‚Äôs also best to keep the experience off of social media. Tweets and blog posts can be used against you in court. It‚Äôs best to limit your communication to the absolute minimum lest you accidentally harm your chances in a personal injury trial.  4) Make Sure the Police Take Your Statement  Almost 40% of police reports don‚Äôt include a statement from the pedestrian, particularly if they‚Äôre sent to urgent care. The police must record your version of events. Your voice matters, so don‚Äôt be afraid to question the police report. This paperwork can be amended to reflect the situation more accurately. Call a lawyer if the officer refuses to take your statement or fix inaccuracies.  5) Start Making an Insurance Claim  Once you‚Äôve dealt with the urgent aspects of your collision, it‚Äôs time to phone the driver‚Äôs insurance company to launch a claim. It‚Äôs best to limit your narrative to the essential facts, no matter how much they pressure you into providing more details. You‚Äôre not required to disclose facts about your medical care, police report, or partial fault.  6) Keep Track of Follow-Up Care  The more detailed your medical care is, the stronger your case will be, so go to all your recommended follow-up appointments. Request diagnostics if necessary. Keep an ongoing record of your medical bills and transportation costs. If you miss time off work, add your lost income to your records. These details will ultimately go to an insurer, but it‚Äôs best to seek legal advice before you hand them over.  Personal injury settlements can be difficult to secure without legal help. Insurers and at-fault parties are notorious for low-balling victims, but you can build a successful case with the right assistance. You need someone in your corner, no matter how strong or resourceful you are.

MONONGALIA COUNTY, W.Va. An accident causing a diesel fuel spill closed a portion of I-68 in the Cheat Lake area Tuesday afternoon.  The accident involved a semi-truck on I-68 at mile marker 11 at 2 p.m. and closed both westbound lanes.  Crews were able to clean up 30 to 40 gallons of diesel fuel and reopen all lanes of traffic by 3:15 p.m.  No injuries have been reported.

DINWIDDIE ‚Äì A bear caused a rear‚Äìend crash Monday night on Interstate 85, the same day one was spotted earlier in Petersburg.  State police said the bear was crossing the southbound lanes of I-85 about two miles north of the DeWitt exit when the driver of a sports-utility vehicle slammed on the brakes to avoid hitting it. Another SUV, however, was not so fortunate and wound up hitting both the bear and the back of the first SUV.  No one inside either vehicle was injured. Witnesses told state police the bear ran away from the scene.  Earlier Monday, Petersburg Police reported a bear sighting near the Henry William Townhouses at the intersection of Lee Avenue and South Street. Authorities were encouraging anyone who may see the bear not to approach it and instead call police at (804) 732-4222 or the Virginia Department of Games and Inland Fisheries at (804) 367-1000.  A Petersburg Police spokesperson told The Progress-Index no other sightings were reported in the city.  Black bears are a common sight anywhere in Virginia, according to the state Department of Wildlife Resources. While seen sporadically along the coast, a DWF map indicates these animals can be found most anywhere in the state because they adapt so easily to their surroundings.  ‚ÄúThey prefer habitats that provide cover, such as a densely wooded mature oak forests or swampy area in the coastal plain, and easily accessible food resources,‚Äù the DWF website said.  The National Park Service says black bears are far less aggressive than brown or any other type of bear and will usually avoid human contact. However, authorities remind people that despite their temperment, black bears still are wild animals and could attack if provoked. Therefore, it is wise to let a black bear alone should you see one.  Bill Atkinson (he/him/his) is an award-winning journalist who covers breaking news, government and politics. Reach him at batkinson@progress-index.com or on Twitter at @BAtkinson_PI.

On May 12, 2023, Virginia State Police were called to investigate a traffic crash involving a pedestrian on the Eastern Shore. The crash occurred at approximately 2:35PM., on Wartown Road at Stewart Wharf Road, in Exmore, on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.  Currently, preliminary investigations reveal that a 19 year old male victim, was standing on the side of the roadway, in the grassy area, working with the installation of cable wires. During this time, it is unclear what occurred due to the fact that there were no witnesses to the incident until after the fact. Other workers were in the wooded area when the incident occurred, and upon exiting the wooded area, they found the victim in the ditch, injured. The co-workers have stated it was possibly a late model burgundy vehicle, and also that the burgundy vehicle was being pulled by tan colored truck. No registration to either vehicle could be provided. Victim was taken to local hospital and later flown to Norfolk General Hospital with serious but non-life threatening injuries.  Virginia State Police is reaching out to the community for any witnesses who may have seen this incident, or notice anything prior to the incident, at the time of the incident, or after the incident in the vicinity of Wartown Road. Currently the victim has not provided a statement to what had occurred that afternoon. Anyone with information are asked to contact state police at (757) 424-6800 or by email at [email protected].  .

Shipment from Modern Warfare is one of Call of Duty's most famous maps. So famous, it actually got a revamp for the likes of Vanguard and Modern Warfare 2 (where it was set on a ship).  Its somewhat simple design, which sees a collection of vacant containers for players to shoot their way around, is a mainstay of the series. However, the original map nearly didn't make its way into Call of Duty at all. As hard as it is to imagine now, Shipment's inclusion in 2007's Modern Warfare was "truly an accident".  Watch on YouTube Here is Shipment in 2022's Modern Warfare 2.  Speaking to Dexerto, Infinity Ward multiplayer design director Geoff Smith shared more backstory on Shipment's genesis.  "There's little happy experiments. Things that worked out, things that didn't work out for whatever reason," Smith said, before admitting Shipment is the "bane of his existence".  Smith stated the map was originally conceived with split-screen in mind, and the team at Infinity Ward used Shipment for internal tests. It was then included in the broader "playlist script" for Modern Warfare, but the developer "forgot" to remove it before the game's final release.  After that, there was "no going back," Smith recalled.  It is hard to imagine Call of Duty without Shipment. Even those with only a vague familiarity with the series can often name it as one of the franchise's maps. While it may have been included by accident, at least the end result was a happy one.  After all, we are now 16 years on from its first iteration, and here I am still writing about it.

Home > Television Source: Instagram/@jacksonpace Does Wyatt Die In '9-1-1: Lone Star?' Here's What Really Happened! The Season 4 finale of '9-1-1: Lone Star' is sure to send fans into a frenzy, as the fate of Judd and Marlene's son, Wyatt, hangs in the balance. Here's what we know about his deadly accident! By D.M. May 16 2023, Published 10:00 p.m. ET  The latest chapter of 9-1-1: Lone Star has been nothing short of exciting. The show, which first premiered in 2020, sees its cast battling a few unexpected surprises in Season 4. In the May 9 episode, the group was stunned when Judd Ryder and Marlene Harris‚Äô son, Wyatt, is injured in a terrible bicycle accident ‚Äì leaving some fans to wonder if he will die in the season finale. Before taking a peek into Wyatt‚Äôs seemingly tragic fate, let‚Äôs look back to his time on the popular show.  Article continues below advertisement  Wyatt, played by Jackson Pace, joined the cast in Season 3. The teenager, who was raised by his mother, discovers that Judd is his father through an online genetics database. However, Judd and Wyatt‚Äôs relationship gets off to a rocky start, due to their conflicting lifestyles. But after being seemingly disappointed by his son‚Äôs veganism and disinterest in hunting, Judd eventually comes around and the two form a strong bond.  Source: Fox Judd Ryder and Grace Ryder in '9-1-1: Lone Star'  Article continues below advertisement  Wyatt later decided he wanted to follow in his father‚Äôs footsteps and dropped out of college to enroll in the firefighter academy. However, Wyatt is ultimately rejected by the Austin Fire Department. Judd then steps in to help his son train for his next enrollment attempt. Despite Wyatt‚Äôs seemingly hopeful future, the aspiring firefighter is now fighting for his life, as fans are searching for answers about his fate.  Source: YouTube/Happy Time Grace help Judd and Wyatt come together as family | 9-1-1 lone star season3 | the ATX  Article continues below advertisement  Wyatt was permanently injured by the accident.  The Season 4 finale of 9-1-1: Lone Star is sure to please fans. Owen Strand (Rob Lowe) is faced with an impossible decision after his brother Robert asks for assistance in ending his own life. Robert‚Äôs request comes on the heels of his Huntington‚Äôs disease diagnosis ‚Äì a fatal condition that causes the deterioration of brain cells. However, Robert is not the only character whose fate hangs in the balance, as fans are also wondering if Wyatt survived his bicycle accident.  Wyatt does not die from the injuries he sustained in the bike accident, but he was left permanently scared. During the two-hour season finale, Wyatt appeared to be in good spirits while recovering in the hospital. Despite his optimism, Wyatt‚Äôs condition left him partially paralyzed. Doctors revealed to Marlene, who is Wyatt‚Äôs acting power of attorney, that he was slowly losing function in his legs and may never be able to walk again.  Article continues below advertisement  Source: Fox Jim Parrack as Judd Ryder in '9-1-1: Lone Star'  Understandably, the news shook Marlene to the core as she grappled with how to reveal the prognosis to the aspiring fire fighter. Example video title will go here for this video  SAN JOAQUIN COUNTY, Calif. ‚Äî A driver died after being hit by a big rig in San Joaquin County.  The California Highway Patrol said the crash between a big rig and a gray Toyota SUV was reported around 11:45 a.m. along Highway 88 at Alpine Road.  Officials said the big rig was hauling 68 live cattle in it's trailer and was heading westbound along Highway 88 while the Toyota was northbound on Alpine Road.  According to CHP, the big rig driver was approaching a traffic signal when it turned red before he reached the intersection. The Toyota's signal turned green and the driver went into the intersection at the same time as the big rig.  Police said the big rig hit the left side of the car and rolled onto its right side with the Toyota under the cattle trailer.  The big rig driver was able to get out of his vehicle and had no visible injuries. However, the Toyota driver died from her injuries on scene was pronounced dead on scene.  Police said drugs and alcohol don't appear to be a factor in the crash.  WATCH ALSO:

Leah Androski  reporter@greenepublishing.com  On Saturday, May 6, Steven and Maisie Cotrell were involved in a serious buggy accident. Steven was riding alongside family and friends when something on his buggy broke. Maisie and Steven are both recovering from injuries obtained from the accident. Steven has multiple surgeries ahead and six-to-eight months on the road to recovery. His family encourages family and friends to pray, call or text, or drop by and visit while he is recovering. They also encourage the support of the fundraiser set up by his work family.  The Cotrell Family Fundraiser is being held on Sunday, May 21, from 11 a.m. to three p.m. at the Courthouse lawn in Madison County, Fla. Food will be offered from slow-smoked whole Boston butt, plates of Boston butt/pulled pork with a side of baked beans and potato salad plus a drink, and funnel cakes. The whole Boston butt is $30 and will need to be pre-ordered and paid in advance. The plates of Boston butt/pulled pork with sides of baked beans, potato salad, and a drink are $15. The funnel cakes are $5. A raffle is also being held at the fundraiser. Red tickets for the raffle are $20 and blue tickets are $30.  The deadline for ordering whole Boston butts will be Wednesday, May 17. To pre-order Boston butt call (850)-253-5107. The Cotrell family thanks everyone for their support.  Share this:

A Houston man has been confirmed as the person killed in a fatal accident that occurred early Sunday morning in Navasota.  Navasota Police responded to the scene of a commercial motor vehicle versus pedestrian crash that occurred around 4:30am on Highway 6 Southbound between Highway 90 and Highway 105 East.  Officers found a male subject laying in the middle of the highway. The man was found to be deceased and had no identification.  Approximately 100 yards south, police located a dump truck laying on its side in the median.  The driver of the dump truck told police that it was dark and raining heavily. He saw an object in the middle of the roadway, and upon getting closer realized it was a person.  He attempted an evasive maneuver to try to avoid hitting the man, but ultimately still struck him, and then lost control and rolled over in the median.  The pedestrian, who has been identified as 37-year-old Michael Robertson, was pronounced dead by Justice of the Peace Mark Laughlin.  The driver was treated at the scene for minor injuries.  On Monday, investigators were able to identify Robertson and notify his next of kin.  Police say that Robertson had been walking northbound in the main lanes of Highway 6 prior to being struck.

Doniphan, MO. ‚Äì An ATV crash on private property ended with serious injuries for the driver.  This happened roughly 10 miles West of Doniphan at 6:30 p.m. on Sunday and involved the use of a 1982 Honda 3-wheeler. Virgil Patterson, 47, was riding the vehicle when he ran off the left side of the roadway; the vehicle then overturned.  Advertisement  Patterson was not wearing a safety device and sustained serious injuries. He was transported by Survival Flight air ambulance to St. Bernards Medical Center in Jonesboro, AR. for treatment.  The investigator of this crash was Sergeant B.L. Riefle, with the assistance of Trooper C.E. Leach, and Trooper J.D. Conover, all of Troop E of the Missouri State Highway Patrol.

PTI  Pondugallu, May 17  Six women labourers were killed and as many injured after the auto-rickshaw they were travelling in was hit by a speeding truck at a village in Palnadu district early on Wednesday, police said.  The accident occurred in the small hours of Wednesday when the women from neighbouring Telangana were proceeding to Pulipadu village in Palnadu district in the state to harvest chillies.  ‚ÄúA lemon-laden truck from Guduru heading to Lucknow hit the auto-rickshaw around 4.42 am and sped away,‚Äù Gurajala Sub-Divisional Police Officer A Pallapu Raju said.  Those injured were shifted to a hospital in Miriyalaguda in Telangana, where they are undergoing treatment, he said.  All the six women were part of a 12-member party travelling in the three-wheeler.  A case has been registered under Sections 304 (A) and 337 of the IPC.

Although it is possible the jury made a mistake when it handed down a guilty verdict, neither Carlson nor Rittenhouse nor Abbott tried to argue the case on the merits. Instead, they made a simple assumption: that any violence against a left-wing protester is justified on its face. Perry had lived out the right-wing fantasy of lethal violence in defense of ‚Äúorder.‚Äù By their lights, he had done nothing wrong.  Prominent conservatives have taken the same view of Daniel Penny, the 24-year-old assailant in the killing of Jordan Neely in a New York City subway car this month. What we know is that Neely, who was homeless, was erratic and acting hostile toward other passengers. Witnesses said he had not attacked anyone. At some point, Penny, a former Marine, placed Neely in a chokehold, which killed him. Two other passengers restrained Neely while he struggled on the ground. Penny is now charged with second-degree manslaughter.  We don‚Äôt know much, yet, about Penny‚Äôs mind-set or motivation during his confrontation on the subway. But this has not stopped conservatives from valorizing him in the same way they valorized Rittenhouse and Perry. ‚ÄúThe Marine who stepped in to protect others is a hero,‚Äù said Greene, now a congresswoman. The decision to charge Penny, said the Fox News host Greg Gutfeld, was ‚Äúpro-criminal‚Äù and ‚Äúanti-hero.‚Äù  In a testament to conservative enthusiasm for Penny, an online fund-raiser has raised more than $2 million for his legal defense. And DeSantis, now angling for the Republican presidential nomination, stepped in with a message of support. ‚ÄúWe must defeat the Soros-Funded DAs, stop the Left‚Äôs pro-criminal agenda, and take back the streets for law abiding citizens,‚Äù he said on Twitter. ‚ÄúWe stand with Good Samaritans like Daniel Penny. Let‚Äôs show this Marine ‚Ä¶ America‚Äôs got his back.‚Äù  It‚Äôs the same language, the same tropes, the same ideas. In listening to conservative fans of Rittenhouse, Perry and Penny, you would never know that there were actual people on the other side of these confrontations. You would never know that those people were, in life, entitled to the protection of the law and that they are, in death, entitled to a full account of the last moments of their lives, with legal responsibility for the men who killed them, if that‚Äôs what a jury decides.

Local News  By Long Island Published: May 16 2023  A boating accident on Centre Island resulted in a teen going missing, prompting a multi-agency search.  Water emergency strikes Centre Island as an 18-year-old male and a 19-year-old male went boating on a 25‚Äô sailboat. According to the Public Information Office, the incident happened on Monday, May 15, 2023, at 11:30 pm.  Reports have it that the 19-year-old male fell into the water and his 18-year-old companion was unable to locate him. He then reached out to another friend who was onshore, and together with two other males, they took a boat and located the sailboat with the 18-year-old, but they could not find the missing male.  A search operation was launched by several agencies, including The Nassau County Police Marine Bureau, Nassau County Police Emergency Services, Nassau County Police Aviation Bureau, NYPD Aviation Bureau, US Coast Guard, Oyster Bay Constable, Bayville Fire Department, and the Oyster Bay Fire Department. However, they were unable to locate the missing male.  The investigation into the incident is ongoing, and more details are expected to emerge in due course. Water safety experts advise that all boaters should wear life jackets at all times while on the water, and they should inform someone of their itinerary before setting out.

PITTSFORD, N.Y. ‚Äî Braden Shattuck can't quite explain why he was so intent on spending a not-insignificant portion of his childhood hitting 30-yard pitch shots from one side of his family's backyard in the Philadelphia suburbs to the other.  Where some might see monotony, Shattuck saw opportunity. There was something about the feel of that first plastic set of clubs in his hands. Something about the challenge of firing to an imaginary pin. Something about the game that gripped him early and never let go.  "He was obsessed with (golf)," Scott Shattuck said of his son. "We had to almost drag him inside the house."  So yes, Shattuck always believed there was a chance he'd make it to the sport's biggest stage. Yet the 4-year-old who took delight in tearing up his parents' yard deep into the twilight couldn't have imagined the circuitous route that brought the now-28-year-old to the 2023 PGA Championship.  The 12-footer for par that Shattuck drained to win the PGA Professional Championship in New Mexico last month assured him of a spot in the strongest field of the year starting Thursday at Oak Hill.  It also served as a testament to the relentlessness of a self-professed grinder who was forced to rebuild his swing from the ground up following a car accident in 2019 that resulted in multiple herniated disks in his lower back and made even walking difficult.  The player who would spend 12 hours a day during the summer as a kid pounding ball after ball on the practice range spent the better part of two years watching the guys he competed with on the mini-tour circuit climb the ladder while he went through countless hours of physical therapy and wondered if he'd ever be able to swing something close to pain-free again.  "Physically you can't even play golf, and mentally it's tough because now what else do you do with your time," Shattuck said. "It took a lot to get over that hurdle."  So Shattuck poured himself into his work as an assistant golf pro, showing others how to fix their swings while trying to devise a way to tweak his own.  "It was more of an experiment than anything," he said. "I knew what exactly in my golf swing hurt, so I figured if I could do something with my setup and my golf swing to take some pressure off of those areas, that even if I didn't fully heal that maybe I could still swing a golf club with minimal pain."  After a two-year sabbatical, his game slowly returned, though not quite the same as before. A more upright stance cost him some distance with his irons, though he has compensated by finding a few more yards with his driver. And the days of planting himself at the range for hours on end are long gone.  The pain is manageable, at least most of the time. He abandoned Korn Ferry Tour qualifying after the first round last fall when his back flared up out of nowhere. His preparation includes a series of stretching exercises and twice-weekly visits to a physical therapist, all of it tinged with just a hint of uncertainty when he wakes up in the morning.  Shattuck is confident his back and his game are in good enough shape to make the cut this weekend. Asking for anything beyond that, at least for now, is just being greedy.  While the vast majority of the 156-man field plays golf for a living, Shattuck remains primarily a teacher. The morning after he got back from his victory in New Mexico ‚Äî a win that earned Shattuck $60,000, a berth into the PGA and an exemption into six events in the 2024 season ‚Äî he was back at Rolling Green Golf Club in Springfield, about 15 miles west of downtown Philadelphia.  There were slices to fix. Hooks to solve. A love for the game to impart the way his father did to him as a kid. The younger Shattuck was 14 when he beat his father for the first time, shooting a 67 from the back tees at The Golf Course at Glen Mills while the adults in the group turned to his father with eyebrows raised.  "Braden would go around (with us) and (they'd) be like, 'Damn, this kid can play,'" Scott Shattuck said with a laugh.  Sure, his son would prefer to play with a back that doesn't require so much maintenance. Yet the unwanted sabbatical brought on by the car accident also shifted Shattuck's perspective.  "I had a little bit more of an intense outlook when I was younger," he said. "Now I just feel a lot more fortunate to be out here. I feel like I'm playing with house money so it feels more relaxed."  At least until he stands on the tee at 7 a.m. on Thursday as part of the first group out on the East Course, a moment that seemed so far away when he was tearing up the backyard as a kid ‚Äî and even farther during his long recovery following the accident ‚Äî finally at hand.  Maybe the nerves he fended off during the arduous process of getting here will make a brief appearance. He's not sure.  "That's a great question," he said with a laugh. "I think we're all going to find out the answer to that one at the same time."

Two people were injured in a two vehicle accident Monday in Lake of the Woods County.  According to the Minnesota State Patrol, ‚Äúa Semi Truck and Grand Marquis were both traveling westbound on Highway 11. The Semi Truck then started to make a right turn into a PVA. The Grand Marquis driver did not see the turn and collided into the Semi Truck.‚Äù  The driver of the Grand Marquis, Clarence John Sindelir, (89) of Baudette and passenger, Mavis Adell Brandli, (89) of Warroad, were taken to Lakewood Health Center and treated for injuries troopers at the scene described as non-life threatening. Max Loya suffered through extensive surgeries and months of rehab, finding inspiration from his family and the medical staff who saved his life.  Example video title will go here for this video  PHOENIX ‚Äî It was a cloudy day in August and conditions were perfect on the dirt bike circuit track.  Max Loya and his friends had been riding all day and were getting ready to call it a day.  "I'm like, I'm gonna go through some more of the track," thought Max.  Knowing the track like the back of his hand, Max rode fast and confidently one last time.  Then suddenly, Max found himself over five thousand yards from  his bike.  "I just remember waking up on the ground. No one saw it happen. But the area where my bike was down step jump, where I know what I had been doing with that jump prior," said Max.  Max was flown from the track to the hospital in critical condition.  "Yeah, he was as critical as can be; he was on life support," said Dr. Jordan Jacobs, a trauma surgeon at St. Joe's Hospital in Phoenix.    "Very early on, with the severity of his injuries, he had at least a 50% mortality rate. He had injuries all over, but the worst was his lungs; his lungs received a very devastating crush injury. They were bruised, they were bleeding, they were collapsed," added Jacobs.  The father-of-two, who was on ECMO and was in a medically induced coma for three weeks.  But weeks after his accident, a glimmer of light shined through.  "I woke up literally three weeks later; I couldn't talk. I had a trach on. And I was like, God, this must have been really bad," said Max.  Max suffered through extensive surgeries and months of rehab, finding inspiration from his family.  "My 15-year-old took it the hardest, I believe. I think she understood just how severe things were. My youngest, I think she's she was more optimistic. I think she's always been used to knowing that Dad always comes home. Dad always makes things okay," said Max  Max is now almost fully recovered and has a new outlook on his life.  "It's changed my perspective on how I want to live the rest of my life, and I want more time with my daughters and more time to create those memories with friends and family," Max added.    Max ended his rehab in December.  On Wednesday- National Trauma Survivors Day- Max will reunite with the medical staff at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center to thank them for saving his life. Friesen says that Gurley, ‚Äúwas a true warrior here at HFR, he leaves a huge void in our team.‚Äù  With extremely heavy hearts we announce the loss of our brother and teamate, Jon Gurley. Jon was a true warrior here at HFR he leaves a huge void in our team. We will march on and keep fighting as that is what he would want us to do, and we will do so in his honor. We‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/CQnOxml3Xu ‚Äî Stewart Friesen (@StewartFriesen) May 16, 2023  A report from WRIC.com states that the accident occurred on Saturday, May 13th, and deputies from the Hanover County Sheriff‚Äôs Office responded to a report of a crash involving an ATV around 11:00 PM ET.  Gurley, who was driving the vehicle at the time of the accident, was transported to VCU Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead. An investigation is underway to determine what caused the crash that killed the 40-year-old.  Friesen, who will look to honor Gurley by scoring a win this weekend at North Wilkesboro Speedway, is riding the momentum of two-consecutive top-five finishes, including a second-place finish at Darlington Raceway this past weekend.  Friesen sits 10th in the NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series championship standings after nine races in the 2023 season.

Buffalo Police report that the accident happened around 10:45 a.m. at the 198 entrance ramp.  BUFFALO, N.Y. ‚Äî Four people were sent to the hospital for treatment following an roll-over accident on Grant Street on Tuesday.  Buffalo Police report that the accident happened around 10:45 a.m. at the 198 entrance ramp.  A Buffalo Fire Air Truck was stopped when it was rear-ended by a car. The car then rolled over.  One person in the car had to be extricated from the vehicle and was taken by ambulance to ECMC.  Another person in that vehicle was taken to by ambulance to the hospital as well. Two firefighters were taken to ECMC for treatment.

A series of wrecks involving a semi truck turned fatal when some Good Samaritans made an unsafe stop to try to help and were fatally struck.  The incident occurred at around 2 a.m. on Sunday, May 14th on US 287 in Wichita Falls, Texas.  According to News Channel 6, a semi truck crashed through a grassy median along US 287 and and overturned, blocking the northbound lanes and much of the southbound lanes. The overturned semi truck then caused another wreck involving two box trucks, but no one was seriously hurt in either accident.  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got a semi truck that‚Äôs overturned blocking the entire north bound lane and into the southbound lanes as well. You got another accident that‚Äôs occurred already, I think maybe both had actually occurred and because people on the south bound lane tried to stop,‚Äù said Sheriff Duke, who responded to the wreck.  After the initial wrecks, Good Samaritans on the southbound side decided to pull over and try to help, and that‚Äôs when they were fatally struck by another vehicle. Duke says that, while stopping to help is appreciated, the safety of the situation should be assessed before stopping.  ‚ÄúYour life has got to be there Safety first before you can save someone else‚Äôs life, and so obviously call in locations, vehicles, what they see, if they saw multiple victims, anything,‚Äù said Sheriff Duke. ‚ÄúIf they can park in that area where they‚Äôre safe, where no traffic is going to run over them, then they can get out and help and leave their emergency hazard lights on.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not immune to being hit by people driving with their cellphones in their face and they‚Äôre just not paying attention, it just happens,‚Äù said Sheriff Duke. ‚ÄúBut they need to put their emergency hazards on and either get past the accident and get in a safe area they can stop in and come back up on the shoulder of the road just to avoid traffic.‚Äù  The incident is still under investigation.

Temple University student Daniel Contreras-Francisco and three family members were involved in a car accident in Connecticut early Saturday morning, killing all four who were in the vehicle, the university wrote in an email to the Temple community Tuesday.  ‚ÄúThis is a tragedy in every sense of the word and we collectively mourn the loss of Daniel and his family members, Joel Francisco Contreras-Paniagua, Lorena Contreras Francisco Reyes and Joel E. Contreras Francisco,‚Äù wrote JoAnne Epps, the university‚Äôs acting president. ‚ÄúThe loss of their lives represents a heartbreaking end to a week that had been filled with such promise.‚Äù  Contreras-Francisco was a student in University College and was heavily involved in Temple‚Äôs fraternity and sorority community, serving as chapter president of Lambda Theta Phi Latin from Spring 2021 through 2022. He also served as vice president of programming for the Multicultural Greek Council and later as council president in Spring 2023. He was just one class short of earning his bachelor of general studies degree.  The university will hold a vigil for Contreras-Francisco and his family at the Bell Tower on May 17 at 8 p.m. All members of the Temple community are invited to attend.

A Mountain View man and woman were injured Tuesday evening after the driver lost control of the vehicle and traveled off the roadway two miles south of Vida on U.S. 63, troopers said.  Nick C. Trusler, 67, of Mountain View was driving his 1998 Ford F150 when he suffered a medical emergency and lost control of the vehicle, traveled off the right side of the roadway and struck a culvert and several trees. The vehicle was totaled. He suffered minor injuries.  The passenger, Sheila R. Haefner, 68, of Mountain View, suffered minor injuries. Both were transported by Phelps Health ambulance to Phelps Health in Rolla.  The driver was wearing a safety device, the passenger was not.  Msgt. S. W. Cunningham investigated the accident. Cpl. B. C. Rowden assisted.

A plane flies overhead Michael Larsen‚Äôs 1954 Cessna 170B at the Oshkosh Seaplane Base. (Photo by Megan Vande Voort)  Seaplane accidents, while few, represent an area of general aviation where targeted training could pay real dividends.  That‚Äôs the takeaway from a new seaplane accident analysis report by the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association Air Safety Institute (ASI).  Funded in part by the Seaplane Pilots Association, the Seaplane Accident Analysis Report 2008 ‚Äì 2022 offers a detailed accident analysis, addressing flight conditions, fleet composition, accident causes, NTSB findings, and more.  The report also includes recommendations to reduce the number of accidents, including several training tips.  ‚ÄúSeaplanes are highly capable and uniquely suited for a wide variety of operations, but seaplane flying carries additional risk ‚Äî due to the environment in which they operate ‚Äî when not flown safely by proficient seaplane pilots,‚Äù says Robert Geske, AOPA Air Safety Institute manager of aviation safety analysis.  During the report period, 2008 to 2022, there were 406 seaplane accidents, with 77 ending in fatalities, he reports.  ‚ÄúFor reference, general aviation accidents during the same period averaged 1,200 to 1,500 with 200 ending in a fatality,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe seaplane fleet makes up less than 5% of all general aviation aircraft, so understanding these types of accidents is valuable to the seaplane community.‚Äù  This report is also important as getting data has been increasingly difficult since the FAA began ‚Äúrepressing‚Äù seaplane activity data in 2015 ‚Äúdue to unreliable reporting and analysis.‚Äù  ‚ÄúFor example, few seaplane aircraft operators report their hours. In addition, aircraft that switch out floats for other landing gear ‚Äî as the season dictates ‚Äî make reporting more difficult,‚Äù it continues.  The limited availability of seaplane flight hours and activity prevents a rate-based analysis of seaplane accidents. It also prevents ‚Äúa meaningful year-to-year comparison and understanding of whether the rise and fall of accidents is attributed to flight activity or to an actual change,‚Äù the report notes.  With all that said, the report finds that one factor dominates the cause of seaplane accidents: Abnormal runway contact (ARC).  ‚ÄúThis is best thought of as a landing surface contact since seaplanes do not need to operate from a paved runway surface,‚Äù according to the report. ‚ÄúThese types of accidents occur mainly during landing (90%), with many resulting from gear-down water landings.‚Äù  The report recommends that a ‚Äúbroader adoption and installation of gear warning systems that aid in identifying the landing surface should reduce accidents in this category.‚Äù  It also suggests more participation by pilots in the Seaplane Pilots Association‚Äôs ‚ÄúPositive rate, gear up‚Äù campaign.  Loss of control in flight (LOC-I) is the deadliest cause of seaplane accidents.  ‚ÄúGiven seaplanes‚Äô unique operating environment, the maneuvering phase is where most of these accidents occur,‚Äù the report notes.  ‚ÄúDedicated efforts targeted at low-speed awareness, distraction prevention, and positive aircraft control could drive down the frequency of fatal accidents,‚Äù it continues. ‚ÄúSeaplane pilots may also benefit from the installation and use of angle of attack indicators.‚Äù  It also notes that the installation of gear warning and advisory systems, which work to identify the landing surface and inform pilots of proper surface or water gear configuration, may drastically reduce nose-over events.  ‚ÄúWhile not as deadly as LOC-I, reducing the volume of accidents would, most likely, positively impact the cost and availability of insurance,‚Äù the report states.  The report concludes with a number of recommendations, including additional training, specifically in aircraft control, loss of control prevention, gear configuration, and operations during maneuvering.  One of the big issues with seaplane training are gaps in flying and training, according to the report, which notes that many pilots swap floats for skis or wheels as the seasons change.  ‚ÄúSeaplane pilots may experience six or more months away from seaplane operations, a situation that hinders their proficiency and impacts their training. Pilots who experience gaps due to seasonality need to take added precautions when resuming seaplane operations. Combating these gaps through a training course could help mitigate proficiency-related accidents.‚Äù  Another critical area for increased training is in decisionmaking, which was cited by the NTSB as a key contributor to seaplane accidents.  ‚ÄúSafety starts and ends with good decisions,‚Äù the report noted. ‚ÄúReminding pilots of the effect their choices have on the outcome of the flight and helping them understand how to mitigate risks will further reduce all GA accidents.‚Äù  You can read the full report at AOPA.org/Training-and-Safety/Air-Safety-Institute/Accident-Analysis/Seaplane-Accident-Report.

A Ridgeland woman died and her passenger was injured in a one-car accident on May 14 outside of Ridgeland, according to Jasper County Coroner Willie Aiken.  Jacqueline Washington, 61, died after being transported to Memorial Health University Medical Center in Savannah from injuries she sustained in the accident, Aiken said.  Aiken said a passenger in Washington's vehicle was transported to the same hospital and was being treated for injuries.  The accident happened a few minutes after 5 p.m. on Lowcountry Drive near Old House Road, which is about three-quarters of a mile east of Ridgeland, SCHP Master Trooper Gary Miller said. A 2019 Chevrolet Malibu, later identified as being driven by Washington, had been heading west when it traveled off the left side of the roadway, striking a tree, Miller said.  No other vehicles or passengers were involved in the accident, the SCHP said.  The accident remains under investigation by the South Carolina Highway Patrol.  This marks the eighth traffic fatality so far this year in Jasper County, according to statistics from the South Carolina Department of Public Safety. Two traffic accidents included in that number were double fatalities.

Sabrina Michelle Strickland is on trial for shooting and killing her boyfriend, 46-year-old Robert Haskell McWaters.  Strickland was 50 on June 28, 2019, when she shot McWaters at the home they rented at 773 Target Road, just outside of Holly Hill.  There‚Äôs no debate as to whether Strickland shot and killed McWaters, but there is as to whether it was an accident or murder.  Strickland‚Äôs murder trial got underway Tuesday with 1st Circuit Assistant Solicitor David Osborne telling the jury that the killing was intentional, not any type of accident.  Osborne told the jury that McWaters was a long-time alcoholic.  ‚ÄúHe was drinking himself to an early grave, but it should‚Äôve been God‚Äôs call when Robert‚Äôs time on Earth was over,‚Äù he said.  Osborne claims Strickland couldn‚Äôt have accidentally shot McWaters because of the multiple safety features that were on gun used in the killing.  He also said Strickland initially told law enforcement officers that McWaters came at her, so she fired the gun at him.  The bullet struck him in his right temple.  Strickland later told investigators that McWaters challenged her knowledge of firearms.  She told investigators that she retrieved her son‚Äôs pistol from a dresser drawer in the extra bedroom.  Video of Strickland‚Äôs interview with investigators was played for the jury.  In it, she told Orangeburg County Sheriff‚Äôs Office Lt. James Shumpert that she was holding the gun and McWaters said, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt know how to do it‚Äù as he sat on a chair at the kitchen table.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm holding the gun. I didn‚Äôt know how to take it (the safeties) off, but I got it off,‚Äù she said.  She claims the gun accidentally discharged.  She put the gun back in its holster, according to authorities, before she called 911.  Defense attorney Jack Swerling told the jury that even though McWaters and Strickland‚Äôs relationship ‚Äúwas volatile and contentious, there was mutual feeling between each other. That‚Äôs why they stayed together.‚Äù  ‚ÄúShe had no intention of leaving‚Äù the relationship, Swerling said.  The jury heard testimony that there had been a couple of calls for law enforcement to respond to the home previously concerning domestic disputes.  In one call, Strickland told responding Deputy Donald Huffman that McWaters kept waking her up while she tried to sleep.  Video footage from Huffman‚Äôs body camera was played for the jury.  Huffman told Strickland to consider going to a magistrate‚Äôs office to try to get the eviction process started to have McWaters leave.  Strickland never sought McWaters‚Äô eviction.  Some of the witnesses the state called on Tuesday include:  Officer Michael Mann, who was employed by the Holly Hill Police Department at the time of the killing.  He was the first officer to respond to the residence at the request of the Orangeburg County Sheriff‚Äôs Office.  The jury watched Mann‚Äôs body camera video recording at the scene.  They saw Strickland was overcome with emotion and crying when Mann arrived at the house.  She was outside while using her phone and pointed to the inside of the home.  Orangeburg County Sheriff‚Äôs Office Deputy Roman Rodriguez, the first deputy to arrive on the scene.  Officer Joseph Henry Daugherty, Strickland‚Äôs ex-husband. Daugherty formerly worked at the Holly Hill Police Department, but wasn‚Äôt an officer there when McWaters was killed.  Daugherty testified that Strickland called him and told him that she‚Äôd ‚Äúhurt‚Äù McWaters.  He told Strickland to call 911. He claims that she told him she did call 911, but no one answered.  Daugherty said he then called the Orangeburg County Sheriff‚Äôs Office dispatch number to report what Strickland told him.  Bruce Owens, of Holly Hill, testified that he let McWaters and Strickland rent the mobile home he had at 773 Target Road.  Owens told the jury that he‚Äôd known the McWaters family for a number of years.  He told the jury that McWaters wasn‚Äôt employed and was an alcoholic.  He also told them that Strickland was employed at tried to make ends meet in the household, but they didn‚Äôt always pay their rent on time.  Orangeburg County Sheriff‚Äôs Office Lt. William McCormick told the jury about photos he took at the crime scene, which included the shell casing from the bullet that was fired, the holstered firearm and various interior views of the home.  The trial will resume on Tuesday at 9:30 a.m. The trial is expected to last three or four days.  Circuit Judge Diane Goodstein is presiding.

NEW HANOVER COUNTY, N.C. (WECT/Gray News) ‚Äì A store employee was killed after getting trapped by a forklift at a Habitat for Humanity ReStore center in southeastern North Carolina.  According to a spokesperson with the New Hanover County Sheriff‚Äôs Office, deputies responded to reports of a person trapped between the forklift and a counter Friday just before 3 p.m.  The sheriff‚Äôs office said the employee was taken to the hospital where the N.C. Department of Labor said they died the next day from their injuries.  ‚ÄúThe N.C. Department of Labor‚Äôs Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) Division has been informed of the incident and opened an inspection,‚Äù a spokesperson for NCDOL told WECT.  ‚ÄúCape Fear Habitat for Humanity is deeply saddened by the loss of a ReStore employee who died,‚Äù Cape Fear Habitat for Humanity Executive Director Lauren McKenzie said in a statement.  McKenzie went on to say the organization is investigating and will take appropriate measures to prevent similar accidents in the future.  Copyright 2023 WECT via Gray Media Group, Inc. All rights reserved.

Oconomowoc family advocates for safer bike paths after daughter killed in accident  OCONOMOWOC, Wis. (CBS 58) -- An Oconomowoc family is advocating for safer bike paths after their daughter and sister, Sarah Debbink Langenkamp, was killed in an accident in August 2022.  Langenkamp was biking in Bethesda, Maryland when the driver of a semi-truck hit and killed her while turning right into a parking lot.  "All that white line is, is an invitation. It's a death trap to bicyclists who think they're safe because they're in a bike lane," Dirk Debbink, Langenkamp's father, said.  Langenkamp's family immediately channeled their pain into action by gaining the attention of U.S. lawmakers who sponsored the Sarah Debbink Langenkamp Active Transportation Act.  "It can't bring Sarah back, but over 1,000 people are killed every year, bicyclists and pedestrians in our country -- but can we make a 5% difference? That's 50 people. Ten percent? That's 100 people that don't have to go through this," Debbink said.  The bill would allocate existing federal funding to allow state and local government to build safer pathways for bicyclists and pedestrians.  "Every day the dollars sit there and not out here, it's another day somebody else could get killed," Debbink said.  The Oconomowoc Common Council voted unanimously to support the Sarah Debbink Langenkamp Active Transportation Act on Tuesday.  "We're going to do our best to help this tragedy become something positive," Oconomowoc Mayor Robert Magnus said.  Magnus and the Common Council are sending the Debbink family off to Washington D.C. with their signed letter of support.  Langenkamp's parents, Dirk and Terry Debbink, are meeting with lawmakers, including Sen. Ron Johnson and Sen. Tammy Baldwin on Wednesday.  "We're all in. Let's make a difference if we can," Dirk Debbink said.  Langenkamp's family told CBS 58 she learned how to ride a bike in Oconomowoc where she grew up. Her passion for biking carried her throughout the world in countries like Uganda and Ukraine, where she served as a U.S. diplomat.  "She loved biking and really committed to commuting by bike in whatever country she was working in," Alicia Bosscher, Langenkamp's sister, said.  Debbink said lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have the chance to come together to support safer biking in communities across the country.

Alfonso Ribeiro is sharing new details about his daughter's recent scooter accident.  While appearing on Live with Kelly and Mark on Tuesday, The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air actor, 51, opened up about what happened to his daughter Ava the day before her 4th birthday.  "On Thursday, unfortunately, my daughter got injured and had to have emergency surgery," Ribeiro told Kelly Ripa and Mark Consuelos. "So it was a very stressful weekend. She fell and had basically road rash on her face and arm, and so they had to scalpel off all the skin."  When Consuelos, 52, asked Ribeiro if Ava is going to be okay, the actor responded, "It's going to be a long process."  Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from juicy celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.  He also revealed that wife Angela had a feeling that something bad was going to happen to Ava.  "The hard part of it is that my wife really listens to her intuitions and she actually on Thursday bought everyone into the kitchen and told everyone, 'I have a feeling my daughter is going to the ER this week. Do not let her do anything that she can get hurt doing.'"  Alfonso Ribeiro/Instagram, Joce zerojack/Bauer-Griffin/GC Images  Ribeiro added, "That obviously wasn't listened to. And so my nanny was running back into the house to get pads and stuff and [Ava] went on a little sit-down scooter anyway."  "How long has your wife been a psychic?," asked Ripa, to which Ribeiro responded, "Unfortunately, most of her life. She very rarely gets things wrong and sees things coming. You don't always listen to that feeling, and I think that all mothers have that beautiful intuition."  "That was very specific but all mothers have that intuition," he continued. "You carry this soul around in your body for nine months; there is a connection that men can never understand that women have with their babies. And she felt something that unfortunately everyone didn't abide by that information."  The Dancing with the Stars co-host and Angela first revealed last Friday that their daughter had emergency surgery after falling off her sit-down scooter.  "Not the kind of day you want the day before turning 4," wrote Ribeiro alongside a photo showing Ava's injuries.  "Just want to give a heartfelt thank you to @kareskinmd for the emergency service and procedure to help lessen the likelihood of scaring. So proud of how brave my baby girl was during the surgery," he added.  Ribeiro and Angela share Ava and sons Alfonso "AJ" Lincoln, 9, and Anders Reyn, 8. The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air alum is also father to 20-year-old daughter Sienna from a previous relationship.

The westbound lanes of Military Drive were shut down at Luke Blvd. near Joint Base San Antonio Lackland.  SAN ANTONIO ‚Äî One man has died in an accident on the west side Tuesday morning, officials say.  It happened around 5:45 a.m. on the 5700 block of Five Palms Drive near West Military and Luke Blvd.  Deputies say a man was walking in the middle of the road when he was struck by a moving vehicle.  He was then run over by multiple vehicle, according to officials. He was pronounced dead at the scene.  The driver of the first car did stop and had to be taken to the hospital with injuries to her wrist.  The westbound lanes of W Military at Luke Blvd had to be shut down during the investigation. The eastbound lanes were also reduced to one lane to allow access to Lackland AFB.  Officials say they have no idea why the man was in the middle of the street. They are waiting for the Medical Examiner to identify the victim.  This is a developing story. LAUDERDALE COUNTY, Miss. (WTOK/Gray News) ‚Äì An 11-year-old boy was killed in an all-terrain vehicle accident in Mississippi Monday.  According to Chief Deputy Ward Calhoun, emergency officials were called to respond to reports of an ATV off the road Monday afternoon.  A family member had discovered Carter B. TALLADEGA COUNTY, Ala. (WBRC) - UPDATE: A multi-vehicle crash Tuesday has claimed the life of a Lincoln woman.  Dana M. Foster, 74, was fatally injured when the 2013 Ford F-350 ambulance she was being transported in collided head-on with a 2006 Freightliner tractor-trailer.  After the initial collision, that ambulance then struck a 2018 Nissan Pathfinder and then a 2023 Honda CRV.  23-year-old Dominic Williams, the driver of the ambulance, and 21-year-old Patrick Ramsey, the on-board paramedic, were both transported to a local hospital for medical treatment. The crash occurred on Alabama 21 near mile marker 219, five miles north of Sylacauga.  Troopers and the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency Highway Patrol Division are continuing to investigate the crash.  Original Story: Officials in Talladega County confirm a motor vehicle accident involving an ambulance on Tuesday.  We‚Äôre told multiple people were injured in the incident.  Officials say the Alabama Law Enforcement Agency is working the accident. They have not yet provided any additional details, but we‚Äôll update this story when we know more.  The following statement was released by Regional Paramedical Services:  ‚ÄúRegional Paramedical Services was involved in a motor vehicle collision this afternoon in Talladega County near the city of Sylacauga. We are currently in the process of gathering information and working with the investigators surrounding the accident. Our immediate thoughts and prayers are with the all the individuals and families involved.‚Äù  Get news alerts in the Apple App Store and Google Play Store or subscribe to our email newsletter here.  Copyright 2023 WBRC. All rights reserved.

An El Dorado man was killed last Thurday in a single-vehicle accident in a rural part of Union County.  Jimmy Owens, 63, was the driver of a 2022 Toyota Tundra that crashed on May 11, according to a preliminary accident report from the Arkansas State Police.  According to the ASP, Owens was headed north on Highway 7 on a wet road in cloudy weather shortly after 6:30 p.m. that day. His vehicle crossed the center line, struck two trees and drifted into an 180 degree turn before coming to rest, the report states.  No one else was injured in the accident, according to the report.  The accident was the second fatal crash on a state highway involving a Union County resident so far this year. Kevin S. Dore, 67, of Smackover died in a single-vehicle wreck on May 2 in an accident that left Patricia E. Mathis, 57, also of Smackover, injured.  Owens was the 199th person killed in a wreck on a highway so far this year in Arkansas, and his wreck was the 179th to result in a fatality.

MEDFORD - When a beloved employee at Lenape High School was hurt in a May 3 traffic accident, the school community responded with an outpouring of support.  An online campaign raised tens of thousands of dollars, with many donations accompanied by wishes of a fast recovery for Mary Jane Mullen, a Lenape secretary for the past 61 years.  But the campaign‚Äôs tenor changed abruptly when Mullen, 79, died from her injuries Sunday.  More: Lenape team among the 15Which teams made our South Jersey Mean 15 softball rankings after the sixth week?  ‚ÄúThe Lenape family suffered a profound loss today,‚Äù Tony Cattani, the school‚Äôs principal said in an update to the GoFundMe account after Mullen‚Äôs death.  ‚ÄúMary Jane was the embodiment of all that is good in our world,‚Äù Cattani wrote.  Mary Jane Mullen spent her career at Lenape  ‚ÄúShe felt a genuine love for all things Lenape, including students, staff, and alumni,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúShe was always ready with a hug, a kiss, and some candy for anyone who needed it.‚Äù  Mullen, a sophomore when Lenape opened in 1958, went to work for the school‚Äôs administration one month after graduating from Lenape in June 1961.  "Her hiring forever changed Lenape High School," a statement from Lenape Regional School District said Tuesday.  Mullen sent thousands of personal notes  It described Mullen, who had led a student club for future secretaries, as "the heart of Lenape High School."  "She approached each day with genuine love, kindness and caring," the statement said.  Over the decades, the Medford resident sent "thousands upon thousands of personalized notes" to students, staffers and Lenape family members, said Carol Birnbohm, the district's superintendent.  She said the notes delivered messages of encouragement, gratitude and love from Mullen, who also bought Christmas ornaments and other gifts for students and staff.  One note, written last month, described Lenape as Mullen's "happy place."  "I wouldn‚Äôt want to be anywhere else. This is my home," it said.  Cattani said graduates who return to the school for reunion activities typically inquire about Mullen.  "Without fail, the first thing they ask is, ‚ÄòIs Mary Jane still here?‚Äô‚Äù  A display of photos in Lenape's 1980 yearbook, Legend, shows Mullen surrounded by smiling students. A sketch depicts a harried secretary typing between wire baskets piled high with papers.  The headlines read ‚ÄúMJ Club‚Äù and ‚ÄúMary Jane, Mary Jane, She‚Äôs Our Girl.‚Äù  Text with the photos describes Mullen as ‚Äúbubbling with effervescence‚Äù and notes she ‚Äúattracts all sorts to her office.‚Äù  GoFundMe appeal started on day of accident  A Lenape graduate launched the GoFundMe campaign on the day of Mullen's accident. It sought to help with Mullen‚Äôs medical costs and to support a scholarship fund in her honor.  According to Medford police, Mullen's car collided with another vehicle at Route 70 and North Main Street.  She was taken to the trauma center at Cooper University Hospital, Camden. The other driver had no reported injuries from the accident, which remains under investigation.  Mullen initially was in good spirits but still had ‚Äúa long road ahead,‚Äù said the appeal, which had raised almost $50,000 by Wednesday evening.  The expressions of hope and affection turned somber on Sunday.  "Mary Jane was a Saint to all who entered her Office Domain," wrote one donor, Daniel Archibald. "She will be missed but hopefully her legacy survives."  ‚ÄúMaryJane is (an) angel now and always has been,‚Äù said another donor, Susan Burns.  Cattani noted members of Burlington County‚Äôs school crisis response team and other school counselors were made available to students and staffers.  ‚ÄúI ask all of our members of the Lenape Family to look after one another as we deal with the loss of our friend and someone who truly exemplified Lenape High School,‚Äù the principal wrote.  He said the school "will plan a special way to memorialize Mary Jane in the near future."  Services will be held at St. Mary of the Lakes Church, 40 Jackson Road, Medford, where friends may call Wednesday from 6 to 9 p.m.  A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Thursday.  Burial will be private.  Jim Walsh is a senior reporter at the Courier-Post, Burlington County Times and The Daily Journal. Email him at jwalsh@cpsj.com.

Pinellas County Sheriff‚Äôs Office  Patrol Operations Bureau  -Major Accident Investigation Team  Conner J Holmes (Driver ‚Äì Deceased)  DOB: 02/28/2004  Vehicle: 2023 Yamaha R7 motorcycle  Harold L Ellerby (Driver ‚Äì Uninjured)  DOB: 10/30/1953  Vehicle: 2015 Chevrolet Silverado  PINELLAS COUNTY ‚Äì On May 16, 2023, at approximately 7:50 a.m., deputies assigned to the Major Accident Investigation Team (MAIT) responded to the intersection of Tampa Road and East Lake Woodlands Parkway to investigate a fatal vehicle vs motorcycle crash.  According to investigators, 19-year-old Conner Holmes was traveling westbound on Tampa Road on a 2023 Yamaha motorcycle, approaching East Lake Woodlands Parkway. A 2015 Chevrolet Silverado truck, driven by 69-year-old Harold Ellerby, made a left turn from Tampa Road into the entrance of East Lake Woodlands. As Ellerby turned and was in the middle of the intersection, Holmes struck the right rear of the truck. Investigators say Holmes was ejected from the motorcycle.  Holmes was transported to the hospital, where he was pronounced deceased. Next-of-kin was notified.  Ellerby was uninjured.  According to investigators, speed appears to be a factor in the crash.  The investigation continues.

CLEARFIELD ‚Äî A Sunset man died in an apparent industrial accident in Clearfield and Utah labor officials are looking into the matter.  The Utah Occupational Safety and Health Division ‚Äúwill not be investigating the fatality specifically but looking for any safety violations that could have caused or contributed to the cause of the accident,‚Äù Eric Olsen, communications director for the Utah Labor Commission, said Tuesday.  A statement from the Clearfield Police Department said Monday‚Äôs incident at Americold at 755 E. 1700 South is being investigated but that ‚Äúinitial information suggests this was a tragic accident.‚Äù The department didn‚Äôt name the 38-year-old man pending notification of extended family members.  The Clearfield incident is the 10th industrial death this year. ‚ÄúSo far this year, including yesterday‚Äôs unfortunate event, there have been 10 workplace fatalities that fall under UOSH jurisdiction and are not attributed to preexisting conditions or sudden health problems such as heart attack,‚Äù Olsen said.  The man was somehow pinned between a forklift and freezer shelves, according to the Clearfield Police Department.  ‚ÄúFirst responders worked quickly and were able to free the victim from the entrapment and rendered some medical aid on scene in preparation for transport to the hospital,‚Äù said the police statement. But he had suffered ‚Äúsignificant trauma to lower extremities‚Äù and died soon after reaching Holy Cross Hospital in Layton.  Newsletter

A teenager was taken to Strong Memorial Hospital after being involved in an ATV accident.  The Monday night accident happened in a wooded area off of Salmon Creek Road, near the intersection with Tuckahoe Road in Williamson. The unidentified 15-year-old was riding through an apple orchard when their view became obstructed causing them to drive off the trail and into a large ditch.  Police say the teen suffered non-life-threatening injuries and their investigation into the accident is ongoing. Following a serious industrial accident at multimetal company Aurubis' plant in Hamburg at around 2:30 a.m. on May 11, 2023, a third worker died on Friday of last week as a result of the accident. A first worker died shortly after arriving at the hospital immediately after the accident, and a second colleague died on the evening of May 11, 2023.  A nitrogen leak occurred during regular maintenance at the Primary Smelter Plant East (RWO). The three Aurubis employees were directly exposed. Rescue workers and the Plant Fire Department were immediately deployed.  "We are deeply saddened by this terrible tragedy," Aurubis CEO Roland Harings said. "Our hearts go out to their loved ones and everyone else affected. We want to express our deepest sympathy. There will be an internal memorial service for the deceased employees at the Hamburg plant on Tuesday at noon." On Saturday, at 9:50 a.m. Bracebridge OPP responded to a collision between a motorcycle and a pickup truck on Highway 118 near Ashley Lane in Bracebridge. The motorcycle operator, a 37-year-old person from Bracebridge, was transported to hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. Police have charged the operator of the truck, a 50-year-old Bracebridge resident, under the Provincial Offenses Act.  May is Motorcycle Safety Awareness Month and Bracebridge Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) is asking all road users to be extra vigilant when encountering motorcycles. Motorcycles are smaller and it can be difficult gauge their rate of speed. Please provide extra space for motorcycles while travelling and always err on the side of caution when making turning movements around them.

Assam SI ( Sub-Inspector) Junmoni Rabha died in a road accident after her vehicle Maruti Alto collided with a truck in Jhakhalabandha in Nagaon district of Assam. Report from sources her body has now been sent to Nagaon for post-mortem.

Scientists have enhanced the efficiency of CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing by threefold using interstrand crosslinks, without resorting to viral material for delivery. This approach boosts the cell‚Äôs natural repair mechanisms, allowing for more accurate and efficient gene editing, potentially improving disease research and preclinical work.  Gene editing is a powerful method for both research and therapy. Since the advent of the Nobel Prize-winning CRISPR/Cas9 technology, a quick and accurate tool for genome editing discovered in 2012, scientists have been working to explore its capabilities and boost its performance.  Researchers in the University of California, Santa Barbara biologist Chris Richardson‚Äôs lab have added to that growing toolbox, with a method that increases the efficiency of CRISPR/Cas9 editing without the use of viral material to deliver the genetic template used to edit the target genetic sequence. Ice wine is rare enough that you may not have heard of it. To tell the story of its accidental origin, you need to know why it's special in the first place. Ice wine, often written as one word ('icewine') in Canada, and known as 'eiswein' in its native land of Germany, is wine pressed from frozen grapes.  The flavor of grape juice comes from the various sugars, acids, and aromatic compounds it contains, but a majority of the juice (roughly 70-80%) is plain old water. When grapes are left on the vine in the winter snow, that water freezes and the flavorful compounds separate. Thus, when the grapes are finally juiced, the water content is far lower than usual, resulting in juice that is more like extremely concentrated grape syrup. After the mixture is fermented for a few months, you're left with one of the sweetest and most flavorful wines in existence. The results are rather magical, and it's all thanks to the ingenuity of German vintners, who adapted to sudden harsh conditions.  Ice

A Tenaya Middle School football coach is being remembered by his family and colleagues.  FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- A Tenaya Middle School football coach is being remembered by his family and colleagues.  Patrick Gossett's life was cut tragically short after he was hit by a train near Fig Garden Loop Park just days after his 27th birthday.  His mom, Christina Torrez describes the support she's been receiving since she lost her son on May 3.  "That support and that love for my son it just -- I love my son to death and to see so many people showing love. That's my son," said Torrez.  One of Gossett's great passions was football.  "He loved coaching. He didn't have kids, so those kids were his kids," said Gina Torrez, Gossett's aunt.  Gossett's funeral will be Wednesday, May 17 at 5:30 pm at Chapel of the Light.  The family has created a GoFundMe page to help cover funeral expenses.  For news updates, follow Nic Garcia on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

The products and services featured appear as paid advertising.  When you're in a car accident, it can be hard to know what to do. When it comes to getting medical attention, Attorney, Shane Smith from Shane Smith Law says he recommends that most people go get checked out after a car accident. Whether you go to urgent care, the emergency room, or to your primary care doctor, it is always good to have a doctor take a look at you. Smith says there are two reasons to make sure you get checked out.  1. You may feel fine, but a doctor could check you out and discover an injury you didn't even know you had.  2.
